title: Oral Presentation Skills — Planning Your Talk
description: Students learn the fundamentals of oral presentation by planning a short talk on a topic they know well. They explore how great speakers organize their thoughts, use eye contact and voice projection, and engage their audience from the very first sentence.
instructions:
1. Ask: What makes a great speaker? Brainstorm qualities together.
2. Introduce the three parts of a presentation: opening hook, body, closing.
3. Discuss the opening hook: a question, a surprising fact, or a short story.
4. Explain the body: 3 main points, each with a supporting detail or example.
5. Discuss the closing: summarize, give a final thought, thank the audience.
6. Model a 2-minute talk on a familiar topic (e.g., 'Why I Love Cooking').
7. Students choose their own topic from a list or their own interest.
8. Students create a planning sheet with hook, 3 points, and closing.
9. Practice reading through the plan quietly to themselves.
10. Pair up and share topics — partners give encouraging feedback.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a planning sheet template with sections for: Opening Hook, Main Point 1 with detail, Main Point 2 with detail, Main Point 3 with detail, and Closing. Have a list of topic suggestions ready (My Favorite Animal, A Place I Love, How to Make Something, A Book I Recommend, Something I Am Good At). Set up a space where students can practice speaking.

slides.text: Think about the best speakers you have heard — teachers, storytellers, people in videos. What makes them great? They LOOK at their audience. They speak CLEARLY and LOUDLY enough to be heard. They are ORGANIZED — you can follow what they are saying. And they seem EXCITED about their topic. Today you will learn to do all of these things!

Every great presentation has three parts: an OPENING HOOK that grabs attention, a BODY with your main points, and a CLOSING that wraps it up. The hook is the most important — it makes people WANT to listen. You can start with a question ('Have you ever wondered...?'), a surprising fact, or a tiny story. NEVER start with 'Um, my presentation is about...'

The body of your talk has THREE main points. Why three? Because three is easy to remember — for you AND your audience. Each point needs a detail or example to make it interesting. For example, if your topic is 'Why Dogs Are Great Pets,' your three points might be: they are loyal, they keep you active, and they make you happy. Each point gets a story or fact.

Your closing should summarize your three points in one sentence, give a final thought or call to action, and end with 'Thank you.' A strong ending is just as important as a strong beginning. Watch me give a sample talk so you can see all the parts in action. [Teacher models a 2-minute presentation.]

slides.prompt:
Choose a topic you know well and care about. Fill out your planning sheet:
1. Write an opening hook (question, fact, or story)
2. Write 3 main points with a detail for each
3. Write a closing sentence and final thought
4. Transfer your key words to index cards (one card per point)
5. Practice reading through your plan quietly
6. Share your topic and hook with a partner — does it grab their attention?

slides.text: You now have a plan for a real presentation! The secret of great speakers is not natural talent — it is PREPARATION. By organizing your thoughts into a hook, three points, and a closing, you have a roadmap that will keep you on track. Next time we will practice delivering your talk with confidence.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the three parts of a presentation? Can they write an engaging opening hook? Can they organize three main points with supporting details? Do they understand the purpose of a strong closing?

parent_notes: Public speaking is consistently rated as one of the most feared activities, even for adults. By teaching presentation skills in elementary school within a supportive environment, we build confidence that lasts a lifetime. The Montessori approach emphasizes that children have something valuable to share — their knowledge, passions, and experiences. The planning sheet provides structure without being rigid. Let your child choose a topic they genuinely care about; authentic enthusiasm is the best antidote to nervousness. Practice at home should be encouraging — focus on what they do well before suggesting improvements. The three-point structure is used by professional speakers worldwide because it works.

title: Fractions Review — Naming and Identifying Fractions
description: Students review fraction concepts by naming fractions from visual models, identifying fractions on number lines, and matching fraction names to their symbolic representations. This lesson consolidates understanding of numerators and denominators using concrete materials.
instructions:
1. Review: What is a fraction? A part of a whole divided into equal pieces.
2. Display fraction circles — identify halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eighths.
3. Review vocabulary: numerator (parts we have), denominator (total equal parts).
4. Show fractions on number lines — connect to fraction circles.
5. Practice naming fractions from pictures: 'What fraction is shaded?'
6. Reverse: draw fractions from names — 'Show me 3/4.'
7. Introduce equivalent fractions visually: 2/4 = 1/2 — they cover the same amount.
8. Students complete a fraction identification worksheet.
9. Fraction card matching game: match pictures to fraction names.
10. Discuss: Where do we see fractions in everyday life?

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out fraction circles with all denominations visible (halves through tenths). Prepare a large number line from 0 to 1 marked with common fractions. Print a worksheet with shapes partially shaded for fraction identification. Create matching cards with fraction pictures on one set and fraction names on another.

slides.text: A fraction tells us about PARTS of a WHOLE. When we cut something into EQUAL pieces and take some of those pieces, we have a fraction. The DENOMINATOR (bottom number) tells how many equal pieces the whole is divided into. The NUMERATOR (top number) tells how many pieces we are talking about. Let us review with our fraction circles.

Hold up the fraction circle for 1/2. The whole circle is cut into 2 equal pieces, and we are looking at 1 of them. Now 1/3: the circle is cut into 3 equal pieces, we have 1. Now 3/4: the circle is cut into 4 equal pieces, we have 3. Notice: as the denominator gets BIGGER, each piece gets SMALLER. 1/8 is smaller than 1/4!

Fractions also live on the NUMBER LINE. Zero is on the left, 1 (one whole) is on the right. 1/2 is exactly in the middle. 1/4 is halfway between 0 and 1/2. 3/4 is halfway between 1/2 and 1. Place your fraction pieces along the number line to see how they match up.

Something amazing: DIFFERENT fractions can name the SAME amount! Look: 1/2 of the circle and 2/4 of the circle cover exactly the same space. And 2/4 equals 3/6 equals 4/8 — they all mean the same thing! These are called EQUIVALENT FRACTIONS. You can check by laying one fraction piece on top of another.

slides.prompt:
Complete the fraction review:
1. Fraction Worksheet: Name the fraction shown in each picture (12 problems)
2. Draw these fractions: 2/3, 5/8, 1/4, 3/6, 7/10
3. Matching Game: Match each fraction picture card to its name card
4. Find 3 pairs of equivalent fractions using your fraction circles
5. In your notebook, list 5 places you see fractions in everyday life (cooking, pizza, time, money, measuring)

slides.text: Fractions are everywhere — in cooking (1/2 cup), in time (quarter hour), in music (half note), and in sharing (1/3 of the cookies). Understanding fractions means understanding how wholes can be divided fairly and precisely. You have reviewed naming, identifying, and comparing fractions — these skills will serve you in every area of math and life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly name fractions from visual models? Can they draw fractions from symbolic notation? Do they understand the relationship between numerator and denominator? Can they identify at least two pairs of equivalent fractions?

parent_notes: Fraction understanding is one of the most critical mathematical milestones in elementary school, and research consistently shows it predicts later success in algebra. The Montessori fraction circles make abstract concepts concrete — children can physically see that 2/4 is the same as 1/2 by overlaying the pieces. Common misconceptions to watch for: thinking that a larger denominator means a larger fraction (1/8 is NOT bigger than 1/4 even though 8 is bigger than 4), and confusing numerator and denominator. Connect fractions to real life constantly: share a snack in thirds, measure ingredients in fourths, discuss how much of a book is finished. The matching game provides repetition without tedium.

title: American Revolution — The Treaty of Paris and War's End
description: Students learn how the American Revolution concluded with the British surrender at Yorktown and the Treaty of Paris in 1783. They explore what the treaty meant for the new nation, what challenges lay ahead, and how thirteen colonies became the United States of America.
instructions:
1. Review the Battle of Yorktown from last week — the final major battle.
2. Describe the British surrender: Cornwallis sends his sword, the army lays down arms.
3. Explain that fighting ended but the war was not officially over.
4. Introduce the Treaty of Paris (1783): Britain officially recognized American independence.
5. Key terms: Britain gave up all land east of the Mississippi, fishing rights, prisoner release.
6. Discuss: What did it FEEL like for Americans? Joy, relief, uncertainty.
7. The challenges ahead: no constitution yet, war debts, governing 13 different states.
8. Students create a 'Before and After' comparison chart (Colonies vs. New Nation).
9. Write a journal entry as a citizen hearing news of peace.
10. Add the Treaty of Paris to the classroom timeline.
materials_needed: Map of the new United States (1783 boundaries)
Images of the Treaty of Paris signing

items: Images of Treaty of Paris signing
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a map showing the new US boundaries from the Atlantic to the Mississippi River. Have images of the British surrender at Yorktown and the Treaty of Paris signing. Create a comparison chart with two columns: 'Before (Colonies)' and 'After (New Nation)' with rows for Government, Leader, Laws, Taxes, and Land.

slides.text: After the Battle of Yorktown in October 1781, General Cornwallis knew the war was lost. He surrendered his entire army — over 7,000 British soldiers laid down their weapons while a band played. When King George III heard the news in London, he reportedly said, 'Oh God, it is all over.' But it took TWO MORE YEARS before the war was officially ended by a treaty.

In September 1783, American and British representatives met in Paris, France, to sign a peace treaty. Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, and John Jay represented America. The TREATY OF PARIS had several key terms: Britain recognized the United States as an independent nation, the US boundary extended west to the Mississippi River, Americans could fish in Canadian waters, and all prisoners of war would be released.

Think about what this moment meant. For eight long years, colonists had fought, suffered, and sacrificed. Many had lost homes, businesses, and loved ones. Now they were FREE — but freedom brought new questions. Who would lead? What kind of government would they create? How would 13 different states work together? The war was over, but the work of building a nation was just beginning.

Let us compare BEFORE and AFTER. Before: 13 colonies ruled by a king, laws made in Parliament, taxes they could not vote on. After: 13 states in a new nation, no king, they would make their own laws and decide their own taxes. But they also had huge war debts, a weak government, and no constitution yet. They had won their freedom — now they had to figure out how to USE it.

slides.prompt:
Two activities:
1. Complete the Before and After chart comparing life as colonies vs. life as a new nation. Include at least 5 differences in areas like government, leaders, laws, taxes, land, and rights.
2. Write a journal entry as a citizen in 1783 hearing the news that the war is officially over. How do you feel? What are you excited about? What worries you about the future? Use at least 8 sentences.

slides.text: The American Revolution changed the world. For the first time, a colony had successfully fought for independence and created a new nation based on the idea that people could govern themselves. The Treaty of Paris made it official, but the real revolution was in the IDEA: that ordinary people have the right to choose their own government. The challenges ahead — writing a constitution, uniting the states, addressing slavery — would test this idea for generations to come.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the significance of the Treaty of Paris? Can they describe at least 3 terms of the treaty? Can they compare colonial life before and after independence? Do they understand that winning the war was just the beginning of building a nation?

parent_notes: This lesson brings closure to the American Revolution unit while opening the door to the next chapter of American history — the Constitutional period. The comparison chart helps children organize their understanding of the enormous changes independence brought. The journal writing exercise develops empathy and historical thinking by asking children to imagine themselves in another time. Be honest about the complexities: not everyone benefited equally from independence. Enslaved people were not freed, Native Americans lost protection treaties with Britain, and Loyalists lost property. These nuances are appropriate for this age group and develop critical thinking. The key takeaway is that the Revolution was about IDEAS — self-governance, liberty, representation — that continue to shape the world today.

title: US Southeast Region — States and Physical Features
description: Students begin their study of the US Southeast region by identifying its states, locating major physical features, and understanding how the warm climate, coastline, and river systems shape the region's character. They explore the Appalachian Mountains, the coastal plains, the Mississippi River delta, and the Gulf Coast.
instructions:
1. Review: Which region did we study last? (Northeast) What made it special?
2. Introduce the Southeast region on the US map — identify the states.
3. Southeast states: Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas.
4. Major physical features: Appalachian Mountains (western border), Atlantic coastal plain, Gulf Coast.
5. Rivers: Mississippi River, Ohio River, Tennessee River — water highways.
6. Climate: warm and humid, long growing season, hurricanes along coasts.
7. Special features: Everglades (Florida), Outer Banks (NC), Mississippi Delta.
8. Students label Southeast states on a blank map.
9. Add physical features: mountains, rivers, coastline, Everglades.
10. Compare Southeast to Northeast — how are they different?

items: US political map showing state boundaries
Blank Southeast region map for labeling
slides.setup_instructions: Have both a political map (showing state names) and a physical map (showing mountains, rivers, coastlines) available. Prepare blank outline maps of the Southeast region for students to label. Gather images of key landmarks: Appalachian Mountains, Everglades, Mississippi River, Gulf Coast beaches, Outer Banks.

slides.text: We have been exploring the regions of the United States. Last time we studied the Northeast — with its rocky coasts, big cities, and cold winters. Now we travel SOUTH to the Southeast region. This is the land of warm weather, long coastlines, mighty rivers, and ancient mountains. It stretches from Virginia all the way down to Florida and west to Louisiana and Arkansas.

The Southeast includes 12 states. Starting from the north: Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee. Moving south: North Carolina, South Carolina, and Georgia along the Atlantic coast. Then Florida, the peninsula reaching toward the Caribbean. Along the Gulf of Mexico: Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana. And inland: Arkansas. Find each state on your map and notice how they fit together.

The physical geography is dramatic. The APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS run along the western edge — they are some of the oldest mountains on Earth. East of the mountains are rolling hills called the PIEDMONT, then flat COASTAL PLAINS stretching to the ocean. The MISSISSIPPI RIVER — America's mightiest river — forms the western boundary, and the GULF OF MEXICO provides a long warm coastline to the south.

The Southeast has a warm, humid climate with long summers and mild winters. This means a long GROWING SEASON — plants can grow for many months. But the warm Gulf waters also create HURRICANES — powerful storms that can be very destructive. Special places include Florida's EVERGLADES (a vast wetland), North Carolina's OUTER BANKS (barrier islands), and the MISSISSIPPI DELTA where the great river meets the Gulf.

slides.prompt:
Complete your Southeast region map:
1. Label all 12 states and their capitals
2. Color the Appalachian Mountains brown
3. Draw and label the Mississippi River, Ohio River, and Tennessee River in blue
4. Mark the Gulf Coast and Atlantic Coast
5. Mark special features: Everglades, Outer Banks, Mississippi Delta
6. In your notebook, create a comparison chart: Northeast vs. Southeast (climate, landforms, bodies of water)

slides.text: The Southeast region is shaped by water — the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Mexico, and the mighty Mississippi River. Its warm climate, fertile soil, and long coastlines have attracted people for thousands of years. Next time we will explore the history, culture, and economy of this fascinating region.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and locate at least 8 of the 12 Southeast states? Can they identify the Appalachian Mountains, Mississippi River, and Gulf Coast on a map? Can they describe at least 3 ways the Southeast differs from the Northeast?

parent_notes: Regional geography builds spatial awareness and helps children understand how physical features shape human activity. The Southeast is rich with contrast — ancient mountains and flat plains, vast wetlands and barrier islands, mighty rivers and ocean coastlines. The comparison with the Northeast reinforces learning from the previous unit while highlighting how geography influences climate, economy, and culture. If possible, explore satellite images of the Everglades, the Mississippi Delta, and the Outer Banks online — seeing these features from above is striking. Children may be curious about hurricanes; explain them as powerful storms fueled by warm ocean water. The 12-state list is substantial; focus first on geographic neighbors and build outward.

title: Read Aloud — Shiloh, Chapters 8-10
description: Students continue reading Shiloh by Phyllis Reynolds Naylor, exploring chapters 8-10 where Marty's secret about hiding the dog becomes harder to keep. They discuss the mounting tension, the ethical dilemmas Marty faces, and how lies create more problems even when told for good reasons.
instructions:
1. Review: What has happened in Shiloh so far? Key events and feelings.
2. Read chapter 8 aloud with expression, pausing at tense moments.
3. Discuss: How is Marty's secret affecting his relationships?
4. Read chapter 9 — the tension increases.
5. Pause: What would YOU do in Marty's situation?
6. Read chapter 10 — significant events unfold.
7. Character analysis: How has Marty changed since the beginning?
8. Discuss the theme: Can a lie ever be justified to protect someone?
9. Students write a prediction for what will happen next.
10. Vocabulary work: 3 new words from today's reading.

items: Character traits chart from previous sessions
slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark chapters 8-10. Review the story so far: Marty has found an abused dog (Shiloh), hidden it from his family, and is struggling with the secrets and lies this requires. Prepare discussion questions that probe ethical dilemmas without imposing answers. Have the character traits chart available for updating.

slides.text: Let us remember where we are in Shiloh. Marty found a beagle he believes is being abused by Judd Travers. He has hidden the dog and built a secret pen in the woods. But keeping this secret means lying to his family — his parents, his sisters. Each lie leads to another lie. Today we will read chapters 8, 9, and 10 to see how Marty's situation unfolds.

[Read chapters 8-9 aloud.] Notice how the author builds TENSION — that feeling of something about to go wrong. Marty is trying to do a good thing (protect Shiloh) but the way he is doing it (lying and hiding) creates new problems. Every time someone gets close to discovering the secret, we feel nervous for Marty. This is called SUSPENSE.

[Read chapter 10 aloud.] This is a turning point in the story. Think about the CONSEQUENCES of Marty's choices. He started with one secret, and it has grown into many lies and difficult situations. The author is showing us something important: even when we have good intentions, dishonesty creates a web that gets harder and harder to untangle.

Let us update our character chart. How has Marty CHANGED since chapter 1? He started as an honest boy who discovered something wrong. Now he is keeping secrets, telling lies, and feeling guilty. Is he still a good person? YES — good people sometimes face impossible choices. The question is not whether Marty is good or bad, but what he will DO next to make things right.

slides.prompt:
In your reading journal:
1. Write a summary of today's three chapters (5-7 sentences)
2. Update your character traits chart for Marty — add new traits you noticed today
3. Answer this question in a full paragraph: Do you think Marty was right to hide Shiloh? Why or why not? What would you have done differently?
4. Write a prediction: What do you think will happen in the next chapters?
5. Vocabulary: Write definitions for 3 new words from today's reading and use each in a sentence

slides.text: Shiloh is a story about doing the right thing — but it shows that figuring out WHAT the right thing is can be incredibly complicated. Marty loves Shiloh and wants to protect him, but lying creates its own kind of harm. Great books like this do not give easy answers; they make us THINK about what we would do. Next time we will read more to see how Marty resolves his dilemma.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child summarize the key events of chapters 8-10? Can they identify how Marty's character has changed? Can they articulate the ethical dilemma and give a reasoned opinion? Can they make a prediction supported by evidence from the text?

parent_notes: These chapters intensify the ethical complexity that makes Shiloh such a powerful read-aloud. Marty is caught between two goods (protecting an animal from abuse vs. being honest with his family) and two wrongs (allowing abuse vs. lying). There is no easy answer, and that is the point. Encourage your child to articulate their own position and support it with reasoning — this develops moral thinking and argumentation skills simultaneously. If your child is upset by the tension, reassure them that good authors create difficult situations so characters can find their way through. The vocabulary work builds language skills organically from meaningful context. Consider reading a chapter ahead so you can prepare for emotional moments.

title: Oral Presentation Skills — Voice and Body Language
description: Students practice the physical aspects of public speaking: voice projection, pace, pausing, eye contact, posture, and gestures. They learn that HOW you say something is just as important as WHAT you say, and practice their presentations with a focus on delivery.
instructions:
1. Review: What are the three parts of a presentation? (Hook, body, closing.)
2. Introduce the concept: DELIVERY — how you present matters as much as content.
3. Voice projection: practice speaking loudly enough for the back of the room.
4. Pace: not too fast (audience cannot follow), not too slow (audience loses interest).
5. Pausing: a powerful tool — pause after important points for effect.
6. Eye contact: look at your audience, not your notes — practice the 'triangle' technique.
7. Posture: stand tall, feet planted, hands free (not in pockets).
8. Gestures: use hands to emphasize points, but not too much.
9. Students practice their presentations focusing on one skill at a time.
10. Partner feedback: What did they do well? One suggestion for improvement.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up an open area where students can stand and practice speaking. Prepare simple feedback forms with categories: Volume (too quiet / just right / too loud), Speed (too fast / just right / too slow), Eye Contact (good / needs work), and one line for 'Something you did great' and 'One suggestion.' Have the timer ready for 2-minute practice rounds.

slides.text: On Day 1 you created a great PLAN for your presentation. But a great plan delivered poorly will not reach your audience. Today we learn about DELIVERY — the way you use your voice and body to communicate powerfully. Think of it this way: your plan is the song, and delivery is how you SING it.

VOICE PROJECTION means speaking loudly enough for everyone to hear, without shouting. Imagine your voice is a ball you are throwing to the person sitting farthest away. PACE means speed — speak at a medium speed. Too fast and people cannot follow; too slow and they get bored. PAUSING is the secret weapon: after an important point, STOP for 2-3 seconds. It lets the point sink in.

EYE CONTACT means looking at your audience, not at the floor, ceiling, or your notes. A trick: imagine a triangle — look at someone on the left, then someone on the right, then someone in the middle. Move between these three points. POSTURE means standing straight and tall. Plant your feet shoulder-width apart. Keep your hands free — no fidgeting, no hands in pockets.

GESTURES bring your words to life. When you say 'three points,' hold up three fingers. When you describe something big, spread your arms. But do not overdo it — constant motion is distracting. The goal is to look CONFIDENT and NATURAL, even if you feel nervous inside. Here is a secret: acting confident MAKES you feel more confident. Let us practice!

slides.prompt:
Practice your presentation in rounds:
Round 1: Focus ONLY on voice projection — speak so the farthest person can hear clearly
Round 2: Focus on pace and pausing — slow down, add 2-second pauses after main points
Round 3: Focus on eye contact — use the triangle technique, look up from notes
Round 4: Full practice with a partner — combine all skills
Partner gives feedback: one thing done well, one suggestion
Time limit: 2 minutes per presentation

slides.text: You are becoming a real speaker! Remember: projection so everyone hears, pace so everyone follows, pauses for impact, eye contact for connection, and confident posture. The more you practice, the more natural these skills become. Professional speakers practice their talks many, many times. Your presentation day is coming soon — keep practicing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child project their voice appropriately? Do they maintain a steady pace with intentional pauses? Can they make eye contact with the audience? Do they stand with confident posture? Can they give and receive constructive feedback?

parent_notes: Delivery skills are best learned through practice, not lecture. The round-by-round approach isolates each skill so children are not overwhelmed trying to do everything at once. Common challenges at this age: speaking too quickly (nervousness), looking down at notes, fidgeting, and speaking in a monotone. Address each gently and specifically: 'Try looking up after each sentence' is more helpful than 'Make more eye contact.' At home, practice in front of a mirror, stuffed animals, or family members. Video recording (with the child's permission) can be a powerful learning tool — children are often surprised by how they appear. Always lead with encouragement before suggestions. The 'triangle technique' for eye contact gives children a concrete strategy instead of the vague instruction to 'look at your audience.'

title: Fractions Review — Comparing and Ordering Fractions
description: Students review how to compare fractions with the same denominator, compare fractions with the same numerator, and order sets of fractions from least to greatest. They use fraction manipulatives and number lines to build visual understanding of fraction size.
instructions:
1. Review: What does the numerator tell us? The denominator?
2. Same denominator comparison: 3/8 vs. 5/8 — same size pieces, more pieces wins.
3. Same numerator comparison: 1/3 vs. 1/6 — same number of pieces, bigger pieces wins.
4. Demonstrate with fraction circles: physically stack and compare.
5. Number line comparisons: place fractions and see which is farther right.
6. Introduce the symbols: > (greater than), < (less than), = (equal to).
7. Practice: students compare 10 pairs of fractions using manipulatives.
8. Ordering challenge: arrange a set of 5 fractions from least to greatest.
9. Students record comparisons using proper symbols in notebooks.
10. Fraction comparison game: draw two cards, compare, bigger fraction wins the round.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 10 fraction comparison pairs of varying difficulty. Include same-denominator pairs (3/8 vs 5/8), same-numerator pairs (1/3 vs 1/6), and some equivalent fractions (2/4 vs 1/2). Create fraction cards for the game: fractions from 1/2, 1/3, 2/3, 1/4, 2/4, 3/4, 1/6, 5/6, 1/8, 3/8, 5/8, 7/8. Have the number line clearly marked.

slides.text: Today we learn to COMPARE fractions — to figure out which is BIGGER. There are two easy rules. Rule 1: SAME DENOMINATOR — the pieces are the same size, so whoever has MORE pieces wins. Compare 3/8 and 5/8: both have eighth-size pieces, but 5 pieces is more than 3 pieces, so 5/8 > 3/8. Easy!

Rule 2: SAME NUMERATOR — you have the same NUMBER of pieces, so whoever has BIGGER pieces wins. Compare 1/3 and 1/6: you have 1 piece of each, but thirds are BIGGER than sixths (cutting into fewer pieces makes each piece larger). So 1/3 > 1/6. Remember: BIGGER denominator means SMALLER pieces!

Let us PROVE it with fraction circles. Stack 3/8 on top of 5/8 — you can see 5/8 covers more space. Stack 1/3 on top of 1/6 — the third is clearly bigger. The number line confirms it too: whichever fraction is farther to the RIGHT is larger. Place 1/3 and 1/6 on the number line — 1/3 is farther right.

We use special symbols: the GREATER THAN sign > points to the smaller number (think of it as a hungry alligator that always eats the bigger number). 5/8 > 3/8. The LESS THAN sign < points to the bigger number. 1/6 < 1/3. And EQUAL means the fractions are the same size: 1/2 = 2/4. Now we can ORDER fractions from least to greatest — just compare them two at a time and arrange.

slides.prompt:
Fraction comparison practice:
1. Compare these pairs using >, <, or = (use fraction circles to check):
   2/5 ___ 4/5 | 1/4 ___ 1/8 | 3/6 ___ 1/2 | 5/8 ___ 3/8 | 1/3 ___ 1/5
   2/4 ___ 2/6 | 7/8 ___ 3/8 | 1/2 ___ 1/6 | 4/6 ___ 2/6 | 3/4 ___ 3/8
2. Order from least to greatest: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/8, 7/8
3. Fraction Card Game: Draw two cards, compare, bigger fraction wins the round. Play 10 rounds and record results.

slides.text: Comparing fractions becomes easy when you remember the two rules: same denominator, more pieces wins; same numerator, bigger pieces wins. And when in doubt, use your fraction circles or the number line — they never lie! Being able to compare fractions helps you in cooking (is 1/3 cup more than 1/4 cup?), measuring, sharing fairly, and all of higher mathematics.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly compare fractions with the same denominator? Same numerator? Can they use >, <, and = symbols correctly? Can they order a set of fractions from least to greatest? Can they verify comparisons with manipulatives?

parent_notes: Comparing fractions is where many children first encounter counterintuitive math: 1/3 is bigger than 1/6 even though 3 is less than 6. The physical fraction circles are essential here — children need to SEE that cutting something into more pieces makes each piece smaller. The two rules (same denominator: compare numerators; same numerator: compare denominators) provide a framework, but understanding WHY comes from hands-on experience. The card game makes practice fun and repeatable. At home, use real-world comparisons: Would you rather have 1/4 of a pizza or 1/8? Would 3/4 of an hour or 1/2 of an hour give you more playtime? These concrete connections build lasting understanding.

title: Healthy Habits — Nutrition and the Food Groups
description: Students explore the fundamentals of nutrition by learning about the five food groups, what each provides for the body, and how to build a balanced plate. They analyze sample meals, categorize foods, and design their own healthy daily menu.
instructions:
1. Ask: Why do we eat food? (Energy, growth, repair, health.)
2. Introduce the five food groups: fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, dairy.
3. Fruits and vegetables: vitamins, minerals, fiber — 'rainbow eating.'
4. Grains: energy from carbohydrates — whole grains vs. refined grains.
5. Protein: building and repairing muscles — meat, beans, nuts, eggs.
6. Dairy: calcium for strong bones — milk, cheese, yogurt.
7. The balanced plate: half fruits/vegetables, quarter grains, quarter protein, side of dairy.
8. Activity: categorize a list of 20 foods into the correct food group.
9. Students design a healthy daily menu (breakfast, lunch, dinner, 2 snacks).
10. Discuss: What happens when we eat too much of one group and not enough of another?
materials_needed: Paper plate for balanced plate activity

slides.setup_instructions: Display a food group poster or create one showing the five groups with examples. Prepare a paper plate divided into sections matching the balanced plate model (half for fruits/veggies, quarter for grains, quarter for protein, small circle for dairy). Gather or print food picture cards representing each group. Have a menu template with spaces for breakfast, lunch, dinner, and two snacks.

slides.text: Your body is like an amazing machine, and FOOD is its fuel. But not just any fuel — your body needs DIFFERENT types of fuel for different jobs. Fruits and vegetables give you VITAMINS and MINERALS to fight sickness. Grains give you ENERGY to run and think. Protein BUILDS and REPAIRS your muscles. Dairy makes your BONES strong. You need ALL of them every day!

FRUITS AND VEGETABLES are nature's superfoods. They come in every color of the rainbow, and each color has different nutrients. Red tomatoes have lycopene. Orange carrots have vitamin A. Green spinach has iron. Try to eat a RAINBOW every day! Vegetables and fruits should fill HALF your plate at every meal — that is how important they are.

GRAINS give you energy — they are your body's fuel for running, playing, and thinking. Bread, rice, pasta, oatmeal, and cereal are all grains. WHOLE grains (brown rice, whole wheat bread, oatmeal) are better than refined grains (white bread, white rice) because they keep the nutritious outer shell. PROTEIN builds muscle and repairs your body — you find it in meat, fish, beans, lentils, eggs, nuts, and tofu.

DAIRY gives you CALCIUM for strong bones and teeth — milk, cheese, yogurt, and butter. Some people use alternatives like almond milk or soy milk that are fortified with calcium. Now look at your plate: HALF should be fruits and vegetables, one QUARTER should be grains, one QUARTER should be protein, and a small serving of dairy on the side. This is the formula for a BALANCED meal!

slides.prompt:
Three activities:
1. Food Sorting: Categorize these 20 food cards into the correct food group. Some foods fit more than one group!
2. Balanced Plate: On your paper plate, draw or paste a balanced meal that includes all five food groups in the right proportions
3. Menu Designer: Plan a full day of healthy eating — breakfast, lunch, dinner, and 2 snacks. Make sure each meal has at least 3 food groups. Write your menu on the planning template.

slides.text: What you eat every day affects how you feel, how well you think, how fast you grow, and how healthy you stay. You do not need to be perfect — but by knowing the five food groups and aiming for a balanced plate at every meal, you are making choices that help your body do its best work. Remember: eat a rainbow of fruits and vegetables, choose whole grains, get enough protein, and include dairy for strong bones.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the five food groups? Can they categorize foods correctly? Do they understand the balanced plate model? Can they explain what each food group provides for the body? Can they plan a balanced meal?

parent_notes: Nutrition education empowers children to make informed food choices rather than just following rules. The five food group model is simplified for this age but provides a solid framework. Avoid labeling foods as 'good' or 'bad' — instead use 'everyday foods' and 'sometimes foods.' The balanced plate model (MyPlate) is the current USDA recommendation and is more intuitive than the old food pyramid. Be sensitive to different dietary needs and cultural food traditions — there are many ways to eat a balanced diet. If your family is vegetarian, vegan, or has allergies, adapt the examples accordingly. The menu planning activity gives children agency and can be used for real meal planning at home. Involve children in grocery shopping and cooking to reinforce these concepts practically.

title: Music — Song Writing Workshop Part 1
description: Students explore the basics of songwriting by learning about verse and chorus structure, creating simple lyrics about a topic they care about, and setting their words to a familiar melody. This creative exercise combines language arts with musical understanding.
instructions:
1. Listen to a simple, well-known song — identify the verse and chorus.
2. Explain structure: verse tells the story (changes each time), chorus is the main message (repeats).
3. Other parts: sometimes an intro, sometimes a bridge (different section between choruses).
4. Discuss rhyming in songs — many lyrics rhyme at the end of lines, but not always.
5. Choose a topic together as a class: seasons, friendship, a favorite animal.
6. Write a chorus together: 4 lines, simple message, rhyming couplets.
7. Students write their own verse: 4 lines that tell a specific story about the topic.
8. Try singing the lyrics to a familiar tune (Twinkle Twinkle, Row Your Boat).
9. Share verses and give encouraging feedback.
10. Discuss how melody and lyrics work together to create feeling.

items: Printed lyrics of a simple, well-known song
Rhyming word lists organized by ending sound
Audio player for listening to example songs
slides.setup_instructions: Select a simple song with clear verse-chorus structure that children know (e.g., 'You Are My Sunshine,' 'This Land Is Your Land,' or a simple pop song). Print the lyrics so children can see the structure. Prepare rhyming word lists organized by common endings (-ay, -ight, -ound, -een, -ove, etc.). Have chart paper ready for collaborative writing.

slides.text: Songs are poems set to music! And just like stories, songs have a STRUCTURE. Most songs have two main parts: VERSES and a CHORUS. The CHORUS is the main message of the song — it REPEATS the same words every time. The VERSES tell different parts of the story — the words CHANGE each time but the melody stays the same. Listen to this song and see if you can hear the pattern.

Many song lyrics RHYME — the last words of certain lines sound alike. 'Twinkle twinkle little STAR, how I wonder what you ARE.' Star and are rhyme! Rhyming makes lyrics catchy and easy to remember. But not all songs rhyme — some use rhythm and repetition instead. Today we will try rhyming because it is fun and musical.

Let us write a CHORUS together! Our topic is [chosen topic]. The chorus should express the MAIN FEELING about this topic in 4 short lines. Lines 1 and 2 should rhyme with each other, and lines 3 and 4 should rhyme. Use your rhyming word lists to find words that work. Remember: keep it SIMPLE — the best choruses use easy words that everyone can sing along to.

Now YOU write a VERSE — 4 lines that tell a specific detail or story about the topic. Your verse is personal — it is YOUR take on the topic. Maybe you write about a specific moment, a feeling, or an image. Try to make lines 2 and 4 rhyme. Then we will try fitting your lyrics to a familiar melody. If the words do not fit perfectly, we can adjust — songwriters do this all the time!

slides.prompt:
Write your own song verse:
1. Choose the topic (the one our class selected)
2. Write 4 lines that describe something specific about the topic
3. Try to rhyme lines 2 and 4 (use the rhyming word list for help)
4. Combine your verse with our class chorus
5. Try singing it to the tune of a familiar song
6. Share your verse with a partner and practice singing together
Bonus: Try writing a second verse with a different detail about the same topic

slides.text: You are songwriters! You learned that songs have structure (verses and choruses), that lyrics often rhyme, and that words and melody work together to create feelings. The songs you hear on the radio all started just like this — someone with a feeling and some words. Next time we will refine our songs, add melody ideas, and perform for each other.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify verse and chorus in a song? Can they write a 4-line verse with at least one rhyming pair? Can they explain the difference between verse (changing story) and chorus (repeating message)? Can they sing their lyrics to a familiar tune?

parent_notes: Songwriting combines creative writing, musical understanding, and self-expression in a uniquely engaging way. Children at this age love music and often naturally make up songs, so this lesson channels that impulse into structured learning. The use of familiar melodies removes the barrier of composing music from scratch, letting children focus on lyrics. Rhyming develops phonological awareness (important for reading) while the verse-chorus structure teaches organizational thinking. Do not worry about musical quality — the goal is creative expression and understanding song structure. Encourage your child to keep writing songs at home. Some children who resist traditional writing will eagerly write song lyrics because the format feels different and fun.

title: Healthy Habits — Sleep, Exercise, and Screen Time
description: Students learn about three pillars of physical health beyond nutrition: adequate sleep, regular exercise, and balanced screen time. They explore why each matters for growing bodies and minds, set personal goals, and create a daily health habits tracker.
instructions:
1. Connect to nutrition lesson: food is one part of health. What else matters?
2. Sleep: children ages 6-9 need 9-12 hours per night. Why? Growth, brain processing, healing.
3. What happens when we do not sleep enough? Trouble focusing, grumpy, get sick more.
4. Good sleep habits: consistent bedtime, dark room, no screens before bed, calming routine.
5. Exercise: 60 minutes of active play per day. Why? Strong muscles, healthy heart, better mood.
6. Types of exercise: running, swimming, dancing, sports, climbing, biking, yoga.
7. Screen time: educational vs. entertainment screens. The 2-hour guideline.
8. Balance: the goal is a daily routine that includes good sleep, active play, AND screen limits.
9. Students create a personal 'Healthy Habits Tracker' for one week.
10. Set 3 personal goals: one for sleep, one for exercise, one for screen time.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a weekly tracker grid with rows for Sleep (bedtime, wake time, total hours), Exercise (type and minutes), and Screen Time (total minutes). Have a goal-setting worksheet with space for 3 goals and action steps. Consider having children track their habits for a full week as a take-home activity.

slides.text: We learned about nutrition — feeding your body the right fuel. But food is only ONE part of being healthy. Today we learn about three more pillars of health: SLEEP, EXERCISE, and SCREEN TIME BALANCE. Together with good nutrition, these four things determine how well your body grows, how clearly your mind thinks, and how good you FEEL every day.

SLEEP is when your body does its most important work. While you sleep, your body GROWS (growth hormone is released at night), your brain ORGANIZES everything you learned that day (like filing papers into folders), and your immune system REPAIRS damage and fights germs. Children your age need 9-12 hours EVERY night. That means if you wake up at 7 AM, you should be asleep by 9 PM — and falling asleep takes time, so be in bed by 8:30!

EXERCISE means moving your body actively for at least 60 minutes every day. This does not have to be all at once — recess, walking, playing outside, riding a bike, dancing, swimming, or any sport counts! Exercise makes your heart strong, your muscles powerful, your bones dense, and here is the amazing part: it makes your BRAIN work better too. Children who exercise regularly focus better, learn faster, and feel happier.

SCREEN TIME means time spent looking at screens — TV, tablets, phones, computers. Some screen time is educational and valuable, but too much replaces exercise, sleep, and face-to-face time with friends and family. A good guideline: no more than 2 hours of recreational screen time per day. And here is an important rule: NO SCREENS for at least 1 hour before bedtime — the blue light from screens tricks your brain into thinking it is daytime and makes it harder to fall asleep.

slides.prompt:
Create your personal Healthy Habits plan:
1. Design a weekly tracker with rows for: Bedtime, Wake Time, Hours of Sleep, Exercise Type, Exercise Minutes, Screen Time Minutes
2. Color-code it: green for meeting the goal, yellow for close, red for needs improvement
3. Set 3 personal goals:
   - Sleep goal (e.g., 'In bed by 8:30 every school night')
   - Exercise goal (e.g., 'Play actively outside for 30 minutes after school')
   - Screen time goal (e.g., 'No screens after dinner')
4. Write one action step for each goal
5. Take your tracker home and fill it in every day for one week!

slides.text: Your body is the only one you get, and how you take care of it NOW affects how it serves you for your ENTIRE life. Good nutrition, adequate sleep, regular exercise, and balanced screen time are not rules made up to limit your fun — they are the recipe for feeling GREAT, thinking clearly, growing strong, and being happy. Track your habits this week and see how small changes make a big difference in how you feel.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why sleep is important for growth and learning? Can they state the recommended hours of sleep for their age? Can they describe benefits of daily exercise? Do they understand the concept of screen time balance? Can they set realistic personal health goals?

parent_notes: This lesson empowers children with knowledge about their own health, which is foundational to the Montessori value of independence and self-care. The recommended guidelines (9-12 hours sleep, 60 minutes exercise, limited screen time) come from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Be realistic about your family's situation — the goal is improvement, not perfection. The weekly tracker makes health habits visible and creates accountability without judgment. Children are more likely to follow through on goals they set themselves rather than goals imposed on them. The screen time conversation should be balanced: screens are tools that can be educational, but physical activity, sleep, and real-world interaction should take priority. Model healthy habits yourself — children learn more from what they see than what they are told.

title: Oral Presentation Skills — Using Visual Aids
description: Students learn how to enhance their presentations with visual aids — posters, drawings, props, or simple slideshows. They explore the principles of effective visual design: simplicity, readability, and relevance, and create visual supports for their own presentations.
instructions:
1. Review delivery skills from Day 2: voice, posture, eye contact.
2. Ask: What do you remember more — hearing facts or SEEING them? Visual aids help audiences remember.
3. Types of visual aids: posters, drawings, photos, objects/props, charts, diagrams.
4. Principles of good visuals: BIG enough to see, SIMPLE (not too many words), RELEVANT (supports your point).
5. Show examples: a good poster (few words, big image) vs. a bad poster (too much text, tiny images).
6. Rule of thumb: no more than 5 words per line, no more than 5 lines per poster.
7. Discuss when to SHOW the visual: introduce it, point to it, then put it down.
8. Students plan their visual aid: what type, what content, what size.
9. Students create their visual aid for their presentation.
10. Practice: present with the visual aid — does it help or distract?
materials_needed: Props or objects related to topics

items: Any props or objects students want to use
slides.setup_instructions: Set up art stations with poster materials. Show examples of effective and ineffective visual aids (make a 'good' poster with a big image and few words, and a 'bad' poster crammed with tiny text). Have a variety of materials available: poster board, construction paper, markers, printed images if available. Encourage students to think about their specific topic and what visual would be most helpful.

slides.text: You have a great presentation plan and you have practiced your delivery. Now we add the finishing touch: VISUAL AIDS. A visual aid is anything your audience can SEE that helps them understand and remember your message. It might be a poster, a drawing, a chart, a photograph, or even a real object. Studies show that people remember 80% of what they see and do, but only 20% of what they hear!

There are three rules for great visual aids. Rule 1: BIG ENOUGH TO SEE — if the person in the back row cannot read it, it is too small. Use thick markers and large letters. Rule 2: SIMPLE — a visual should have very few words. No one wants to read a paragraph on a poster! Use pictures, diagrams, or just key words. Rule 3: RELEVANT — every visual should support what you are SAYING. Do not add decorations that do not connect to your topic.

Look at these two posters. This one has a big, clear image in the center, a title at the top in large letters, and three key words below. You can understand it from across the room. THIS one has 50 words in tiny writing, a small picture in the corner, and five different colors. You cannot read it and it is confusing. Which would YOU rather look at during a presentation? Simple and clear ALWAYS wins.

When you USE your visual during the presentation, follow these steps: 1) INTRODUCE it: 'I made a poster to show you...' 2) HOLD it up or point to it so everyone can see. 3) EXPLAIN what it shows — do not just show it silently. 4) PUT IT DOWN when you move to the next point so it does not distract. The visual supports YOUR words — you are still the star of the presentation, not the poster!

slides.prompt:
Create your visual aid:
1. Decide what type of visual will best support YOUR presentation (poster, drawing, chart, prop, or combination)
2. Plan your visual on scratch paper first — sketch the layout
3. Create the visual: remember BIG, SIMPLE, RELEVANT
4. For posters: maximum 5 words per line, use thick markers, include one strong image
5. Practice presenting WITH your visual aid
6. Get a partner's feedback: Can they see it? Does it help them understand?

slides.text: A great visual aid does not have to be fancy — it has to be CLEAR. The best visuals are simple, large, and directly connected to what you are saying. Remember: you are the presenter, and the visual is your helper. Practice presenting with your visual aid at home. On presentation day, you will have your plan, your delivery skills, AND your visual aid — you are going to be amazing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the three rules of effective visual aids (big, simple, relevant)? Did they create a visual that supports their presentation content? Can they use the visual during their talk without it becoming a distraction? Can they critique sample visuals for effectiveness?

parent_notes: Visual aids give children a concrete focus during presentations, which actually reduces nervousness — they have something to hold, point to, and reference. The three rules (big, simple, relevant) apply to all visual communication and serve children well throughout their education. Resist the urge to make the poster for your child — even a child-made poster with imperfect lettering is more authentic and educationally valuable than a parent-produced masterpiece. If your child wants to use a real object as a prop, encourage it — props create memorable moments. The key insight is that visuals support the speaker rather than replace them. If your child reads every word off their poster, they are using it as a script rather than a visual aid. Help them practice the introduce-show-explain-put down sequence.

title: Fractions Review — Adding Fractions with Same Denominators
description: Students review adding fractions that share the same denominator, understanding that when the pieces are the same size, you simply count them up. They use fraction manipulatives to visualize the addition process and practice with both proper fractions and results that form wholes.
instructions:
1. Review: When fractions have the same denominator, the pieces are the same size.
2. Adding same-denominator fractions: just add the numerators, keep the denominator.
3. Demonstrate with fraction circles: 1/4 + 2/4 — place pieces together — equals 3/4.
4. Show on number line: start at 1/4, jump forward 2/4, land on 3/4.
5. What if the sum equals a whole? 3/4 + 1/4 = 4/4 = 1 whole.
6. What if the sum is more than a whole? 3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4 = 1 and 2/4 = 1 and 1/2.
7. Practice 8 addition problems with fraction circles.
8. Write the equations in notebooks with proper notation.
9. Word problems: 'You ate 2/8 of the pizza and your sister ate 3/8. How much was eaten?'
10. Challenge: Can the student create their own fraction addition word problem?

items: Fraction circles (multiple sets for sums greater than 1)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare multiple sets of fraction circles so students can make sums greater than 1 whole. Extend the number line to 2 to accommodate improper fractions. Write 8 addition problems of increasing difficulty. Create word problem cards with real-world fraction scenarios. Include problems where the sum equals exactly 1 and problems where it exceeds 1.

slides.text: Adding fractions with the SAME denominator is the easiest fraction operation. Think about it: if all the pieces are the SAME SIZE, you just COUNT how many you have! 1/4 + 2/4 means 1 quarter-piece plus 2 quarter-pieces equals 3 quarter-pieces: 3/4. The denominator stays the same because the SIZE of the pieces has not changed — you just have MORE of them.

Let us prove it with fraction circles. Place 1/4 piece on the table. Now place 2/4 (two quarter pieces) next to it. Push them together. Compare the combined pieces to a 3/4 piece — they are exactly the same! On the number line: start at 1/4, jump forward 2/4, and you land on 3/4. Both methods confirm the answer.

Something interesting happens when fractions add up to a WHOLE. 3/4 + 1/4 = 4/4. But 4/4 means 4 pieces out of 4 — that is the WHOLE thing! 4/4 = 1. With fraction circles: place 3/4 and 1/4 together — they fill the complete circle. And sometimes the answer is MORE than 1 whole: 3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4. That is 1 whole (4/4) plus 2/4 left over, which equals 1 and 1/2.

The RULE is simple: same denominator, add the numerators, keep the denominator. 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/5. 3/8 + 4/8 = 7/8. 5/6 + 4/6 = 9/6 = 1 and 3/6 = 1 and 1/2. The tricky part is when the answer is more than 1 — you need to pull out the whole number. Now let us practice with real-world word problems to see how useful this is!

slides.prompt:
Fraction addition practice:
1. Solve with fraction circles, then write the equation:
   1/3 + 1/3 = | 2/6 + 3/6 = | 1/8 + 5/8 = | 3/4 + 1/4 =
   2/5 + 2/5 = | 4/6 + 5/6 = | 3/8 + 7/8 = | 5/10 + 3/10 =
2. Word problems:
   - You ate 2/8 of a pizza. Your friend ate 3/8. How much was eaten altogether?
   - A recipe needs 1/4 cup of sugar and 2/4 cup of flour. How much total dry ingredient?
   - You read 3/6 of a book on Monday and 2/6 on Tuesday. How much have you read?
3. Create your own fraction addition word problem and solve it.

slides.text: Adding fractions with the same denominator is straightforward: same size pieces, just count them up. The key is remembering that the denominator tells you the piece SIZE (it does not change when you add) and the numerator tells you HOW MANY pieces. When you get more pieces than make a whole, convert to a mixed number. This skill appears in cooking, measuring, building, and every kind of math you will study in the future.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add fractions with the same denominator correctly? Do they understand why the denominator stays the same? Can they recognize when a sum equals or exceeds one whole? Can they convert improper fractions to mixed numbers? Can they solve fraction addition word problems?

parent_notes: Adding same-denominator fractions is conceptually the simplest fraction operation, but it establishes patterns critical for later math. The key conceptual point is that the denominator describes the size of pieces (it stays the same) while the numerator counts pieces (it changes). Watch for the common error of adding both numerator AND denominator (1/4 + 2/4 does NOT equal 3/8). The fraction circles make the correct process visible. Problems that result in improper fractions (more than 1 whole) introduce mixed numbers naturally. Real-world word problems ground the abstraction in experience: cooking is especially rich for fraction practice. If your child seems ready, try simple fraction addition while actually baking — measure 1/4 cup, then 2/4 cup, and discuss the total.

title: After the Revolution — Creating a New Government
description: Students explore the challenges America faced after winning independence: governing 13 states with different interests, paying war debts, and the journey from the weak Articles of Confederation to the Constitutional Convention of 1787. They learn how compromise built the framework for American democracy.
instructions:
1. Review: The war is over. America is independent. Now what?
2. The problem: 13 states with different sizes, economies, and interests.
3. First attempt: Articles of Confederation — a very weak central government.
4. Problems with the Articles: could not collect taxes, no national army, no courts.
5. Shays' Rebellion: farmers could not pay debts, the government could not respond.
6. The Constitutional Convention: 55 delegates meet in Philadelphia (1787).
7. Key figures: Washington (presided), Madison ('Father of the Constitution'), Franklin.
8. The Great Compromise: two chambers of Congress (Senate and House).
9. The result: the US Constitution — a framework that still governs us today.
10. Students create a simple timeline from Yorktown to Constitution ratification.

items: Images of Constitutional Convention and key figures
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a simple timeline template spanning 1781 (Yorktown) to 1789 (Washington inaugurated) with spaces for students to fill in key events. Have images of Washington, Madison, and Franklin. Create a simple comparison chart of Articles of Confederation vs. Constitution. The key message: building a government through compromise is difficult but essential work.

slides.text: Imagine you and your friends just won an impossible battle. You are free! But now comes an even harder question: HOW do you all live together? The 13 states were like 13 separate countries — they had different sizes, different economies, different ideas about government. Virginia was huge; Rhode Island was tiny. Some states had slavery; others did not. Getting them to agree on ANYTHING was enormously difficult.

Their first try was the ARTICLES OF CONFEDERATION — basically a friendship agreement between 13 independent states. The central government was very weak on purpose (they had just fought a king and did not want another powerful ruler). But too weak was also a problem: the government could not collect taxes, could not raise an army, and could not settle disagreements between states. It was like a team with no captain.

Things got so bad that when farmers in Massachusetts could not pay their debts and rebelled (SHAYS' REBELLION), the national government could not even respond. Leaders realized the Articles were not working. In May 1787, 55 delegates gathered in Philadelphia to fix the problem. George Washington led the meeting. James Madison came with detailed plans. Benjamin Franklin, now 81 years old, brought wisdom and humor.

The delegates argued all summer. Big states wanted representation based on population. Small states wanted equal representation. The solution? The GREAT COMPROMISE: TWO chambers of Congress — the House of Representatives (based on population, so big states have more voice) and the Senate (two per state, so small states are equally heard). Through COMPROMISE, they created the US CONSTITUTION — the document that STILL governs America today, over 230 years later.

slides.prompt:
Two activities:
1. Create a timeline from 1781 to 1789 with these events:
   - 1781: Yorktown surrender
   - 1783: Treaty of Paris
   - 1781-1787: Articles of Confederation period
   - 1786-87: Shays' Rebellion
   - 1787: Constitutional Convention
   - 1788: Constitution ratified
   - 1789: Washington inaugurated as first President
2. In your history journal, write a paragraph answering: Why was it so hard for 13 states to agree on one government? Give at least 3 reasons.

slides.text: Building a government is harder than winning a war. The Founders had to find ways for people who disagreed about almost everything to work together. The Constitution was not perfect — it did not end slavery, it did not include women's rights — but it created a framework that could be AMENDED (changed and improved) over time. The art of COMPROMISE — finding solutions where everyone gives a little — is one of the most important skills in democracy and in life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the Articles of Confederation failed? Can they describe the Constitutional Convention and at least 2 key figures? Do they understand the Great Compromise? Can they explain why compromise was necessary? Can they sequence events from Yorktown to the Constitution?

parent_notes: This lesson bridges the Revolution unit with the foundations of American government. The concept of compromise is central and applies directly to children's social lives — finding solutions where everyone gives a little is a skill they use on the playground and at home. The Articles of Confederation provide an important lesson about balance: too little government creates chaos, too much creates tyranny. The Founders were trying to find the middle ground. The Constitution is presented honestly — as a remarkable achievement that was also deeply flawed (slavery, women's exclusion). These imperfections are important to acknowledge because they show that democracy is an ongoing project of improvement. If your child is interested, the story of the Constitutional Convention — the secret sessions, the fierce debates, Franklin's witticisms — reads like a political thriller.

title: Southeast Region — History and Culture
description: Students explore the rich history and diverse culture of the US Southeast region, from Native American civilizations through the Civil War and civil rights movement, to the region's distinctive music, food, and traditions that have shaped American culture.
instructions:
1. Review Southeast states and physical features from Day 1.
2. Native American history: Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, Seminole — the Five Civilized Tribes.
3. Colonial history: Jamestown (1607), plantation economy, slavery.
4. The Civil War: the Southeast was the heart of the Confederacy.
5. Civil rights movement: Montgomery bus boycott, sit-ins, marches.
6. Cultural contributions: jazz and blues (New Orleans), country music (Nashville), bluegrass.
7. Food traditions: barbecue, Cajun and Creole cooking, sweet tea, pecan pie.
8. Students create a cultural map of the Southeast.
9. Write about one cultural contribution that interests them most.
10. Discuss: How has the Southeast shaped American culture?

items: Images of historic sites and cultural landmarks
Audio samples of jazz, blues, and country music
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a map for cultural annotations. Gather images of key sites: Jamestown, Civil War battlefields, Montgomery, Nashville. If possible, have short audio clips of jazz (Louis Armstrong), blues (B.B. King), and country music. Have information about Southern food traditions and cultural practices ready.

slides.text: The Southeast has one of the richest and most complex histories of any American region. For thousands of years, powerful Native American nations thrived here — the Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Seminole, known as the Five Civilized Tribes. They had governments, farms, written languages, and thriving communities long before Europeans arrived.

European colonization changed everything. The first permanent English settlement, Jamestown, was established in Virginia in 1607. As plantations grew, the tragic institution of SLAVERY became central to the Southern economy. Millions of enslaved Africans were forced to work the fields. This painful history led to the Civil War (1861-1865) and, a century later, to the civil rights movement that fought for equality and justice.

From this complex history came extraordinary CULTURE. Jazz was born in New Orleans — a blend of African rhythms, European harmonies, and American creativity. The blues grew from the songs of enslaved people in the Mississippi Delta. Nashville became the home of country music. Southern FOOD is famous worldwide: barbecue slow-smoked over wood, Cajun and Creole dishes from Louisiana, sweet cornbread, peach cobbler, and sweet tea.

The Southeast also gave America some of its most important heroes: Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks, Ruby Bridges, and many others who fought for civil rights. Today the Southeast blends its traditions with modern growth — cities like Atlanta, Charlotte, and Nashville are among the fastest-growing in America. The region's history is complicated, but its contributions to American culture are immeasurable.

slides.prompt:
Create a cultural map of the Southeast:
1. Mark historic sites: Jamestown (VA), Charleston (SC), Montgomery (AL), Nashville (TN), New Orleans (LA)
2. Add cultural labels: Jazz music near New Orleans, Country music near Nashville, Civil rights sites in Alabama
3. Add food regions: Cajun cooking in Louisiana, Barbecue across the region
4. In your journal, write a paragraph about ONE cultural contribution from the Southeast that interests you most. Why does it interest you?

slides.text: The Southeast region has shaped American culture in profound ways — through music, food, history, and the ongoing struggle for justice and equality. Understanding this region means understanding America itself: its beauty and its contradictions, its creativity and its challenges, its past and its future.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 cultural contributions of the Southeast? Can they explain the significance of the civil rights movement? Can they identify at least 3 historic sites? Do they understand how history shaped the region's culture?

parent_notes: The Southeast's history includes both inspiring achievements and painful injustices. Present both honestly and age-appropriately. Children at this age have a strong sense of fairness and can process the concept that people were treated unjustly and that brave individuals worked to change that. The music connection is powerful — play actual recordings if possible. Southern food traditions often have deep cultural roots: barbecue techniques came from both Native American and African traditions, Cajun cooking reflects French, African, and Native American influences. If your family has Southern heritage, share your stories. If not, explore a Southern recipe together. The cultural map activity helps children see how geography and history create unique regional identities.

title: Read Aloud — Shiloh, Chapters 11-13
description: Students continue reading Shiloh, reaching the climactic chapters where Marty's secret is exposed and he must face the consequences. They explore themes of honesty, courage, standing up for what is right, and the difference between legal ownership and moral responsibility.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 8-10: What happened? How was Marty feeling?
2. Read chapter 11 aloud — the crisis point approaches.
3. Pause for predictions: What will happen when the truth comes out?
4. Read chapter 12 — major events unfold.
5. Discuss: How do different characters react? Why?
6. Read chapter 13 — Marty takes action.
7. Character analysis: How does Marty show courage?
8. Theme discussion: ownership vs. responsibility — who SHOULD have Shiloh?
9. Students write a response: Was Marty right in what he did?
10. Vocabulary and reading comprehension questions.

slides.setup_instructions: These are pivotal chapters. Read ahead to prepare for emotional moments. Have tissues available — this part of the story is intense. Prepare discussion questions that let children process the moral complexity without dictating what they should feel. Update the character traits chart with space for new developments.

slides.text: We have been following Marty as he hides Shiloh and struggles with the lies he has to tell. The tension has been building chapter by chapter. Today we reach the critical turning point — the moment when secrets come to light and Marty must face what he has done. Let us see how our characters respond when truth arrives.

[Read chapters 11-12 aloud with appropriate pacing and emotion.] These chapters change everything. Notice how the author has been building to this moment — every choice Marty made, every lie he told, every risk he took leads to this point. How do the different characters react? Marty's father? His mother? Think about WHY each person responds the way they do.

[Read chapter 13 aloud.] Marty shows a different kind of courage now — not the secret courage of hiding, but the open courage of STANDING UP for what he believes is right, even when it means facing consequences. This is harder than hiding. It means being honest, accepting responsibility, and still fighting for Shiloh.

Here is the big question: Judd Travers LEGALLY owns Shiloh. He bought the dog with his own money. But Judd abuses the dog, and Marty loves and cares for Shiloh. Who SHOULD have the dog? This is the difference between LEGAL ownership and MORAL responsibility. Sometimes the law says one thing, but our hearts say another. There is no easy answer — that is what makes this a great book.

slides.prompt:
In your reading journal:
1. Summarize the key events of chapters 11-13 (6-8 sentences)
2. Update your character traits chart — how have characters changed?
3. Write a full paragraph answering: Who should have Shiloh — Judd or Marty? Support your opinion with at least 3 reasons
4. Prediction: How do you think the book will end? Why?
5. Vocabulary: Define 3 new words and use each in a sentence

slides.text: Shiloh teaches us that doing the right thing is not always simple or easy. Marty had to lie to protect an animal from abuse, and those lies created their own problems. Now he faces the truth and must find a new way forward. The question of legal ownership vs. moral responsibility appears throughout life — in big issues and small ones. What matters is that we THINK about these questions carefully and act with both courage and compassion.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child summarize the key events of chapters 11-13? Can they analyze character motivations and reactions? Can they articulate the legal vs. moral ownership dilemma? Can they form and defend an opinion with textual evidence?

parent_notes: These climactic chapters may provoke strong emotions. Children who have bonded with Shiloh through the reading may feel anxious, angry, or sad. These feelings are appropriate and valuable — literature that moves us teaches empathy and moral reasoning. Help your child process their feelings by talking about the characters and situations rather than minimizing emotions ('It is just a story'). The legal vs. moral ownership question has no right answer, which is exactly the point. Support your child in forming their OWN opinion and defending it with reasoning. This builds critical thinking and moral development simultaneously. Phyllis Reynolds Naylor wrote sequels (Shiloh Season and Saving Shiloh) if your child wants to continue with these characters.

title: Oral Presentation Skills — Practice and Peer Feedback
description: Students do a full rehearsal of their presentations, combining their content plan, delivery skills, and visual aids. They present to small groups, receive structured peer feedback, and make final adjustments before presentation day.
instructions:
1. Review all presentation components: plan, delivery, visual aid.
2. Set expectations: today is a PRACTICE run — it is okay to make mistakes.
3. Organize small groups of 3-4 students.
4. Each student presents to their small group (2-3 minutes each).
5. Audience members fill out feedback forms: strengths and one suggestion.
6. After each presentation, the group discusses what worked well.
7. Students read their feedback and identify one thing to improve.
8. Second round: students present again with improvements.
9. Compare: How was the second time different from the first?
10. Final preparations: make any last adjustments to plan, visual, or delivery.

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange the room into small group stations with 3-4 chairs facing a standing area. Prepare peer feedback forms with: Speaker Name, Topic, What They Did Well (2 things), One Suggestion for Improvement, and a rating scale for Volume, Eye Contact, Organization, and Visual Aid. Set the timer for 2-3 minutes per presentation. Create a supportive atmosphere — this is practice, not performance.

slides.text: Today is REHEARSAL DAY — your chance to practice your full presentation and get feedback before the real thing. Athletes practice before the game. Musicians rehearse before the concert. Speakers practice before the speech. The more you practice, the more confident you will feel. Today you will present TWICE — once to get feedback, and once to use that feedback.

When you are the PRESENTER: Stand up, take a breath, and begin with your hook. Use your index cards for reference but try to look UP at your audience as much as possible. Use your visual aid at the right moment. Speak clearly and at a good pace. End with your closing and say 'Thank you.' It is OKAY to make mistakes — that is why we practice!

When you are the AUDIENCE: Your job is just as important! Sit quietly, look at the speaker, and LISTEN. After they finish, fill out the feedback form. Be HONEST but KIND. Start with what they did WELL — everyone needs to hear what is working. Then give ONE specific suggestion: 'Maybe speak a little louder' is helpful. 'It was bad' is NOT helpful.

After Round 1, read your feedback carefully. Choose ONE thing to focus on improving. You cannot fix everything at once, so pick the most important suggestion. Then present AGAIN in Round 2. Notice how much better the second time feels — even small improvements make a big difference. This is how professionals get better: practice, feedback, adjust, practice again.

slides.prompt:
Presentation Practice:
Round 1 (15 min): Each student presents to their small group (2-3 min each). Audience fills out feedback forms after each presentation.
Feedback Review (3 min): Read your feedback. Circle ONE thing to improve.
Round 2 (15 min): Present again with your improvement. Audience notices what changed.
Reflection: In your notebook, answer: What improved from Round 1 to Round 2? What will you practice before presentation day?

slides.text: You just experienced the most powerful learning cycle there is: TRY, GET FEEDBACK, IMPROVE, TRY AGAIN. Professional speakers, athletes, and artists all use this cycle. Notice how much better your second presentation was compared to your first — that improvement came from just ONE round of feedback and practice. Imagine how good you will be by presentation day! Keep practicing at home.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child deliver a complete 2-3 minute presentation with hook, body, and closing? Do they use appropriate voice, posture, and eye contact? Can they integrate their visual aid effectively? Can they give constructive peer feedback? Can they identify and implement improvements based on feedback?

parent_notes: The practice-feedback-improve cycle is one of the most valuable learning experiences in education. By presenting twice, children see immediate improvement, which builds confidence and motivation. The peer feedback component teaches both giving and receiving constructive criticism — skills essential for life. At home, be an enthusiastic practice audience. Ask your child to present to family members, stuffed animals, or even the mirror. Each repetition reduces anxiety and improves fluency. If your child is nervous, normalize the feeling: 'Everyone gets nervous, even professional speakers. Nervousness means you care about doing well.' Focus praise on specific behaviors ('I loved how you looked right at me when you said that') rather than general statements ('Good job').

title: Fractions Review — Subtracting Fractions and Mixed Practice
description: Students review subtracting fractions with the same denominator and then engage in mixed practice combining all fraction skills: naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting. This comprehensive review solidifies fraction understanding through varied problem types and real-world applications.
instructions:
1. Connect to addition: if adding fractions means combining pieces, subtracting means taking away.
2. Same denominator subtraction: subtract the numerators, keep the denominator.
3. Demonstrate: 5/8 - 2/8 = 3/8 — show with fraction circles.
4. Subtracting from a whole: 1 - 3/4 = 4/4 - 3/4 = 1/4.
5. Practice 6 subtraction problems with manipulatives.
6. Mixed practice: naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting fractions.
7. Real-world problem set: cooking, measuring, sharing scenarios.
8. Fraction review game: spin the spinner, perform the operation.
9. Students self-assess: what fraction skills are strong? What needs more practice?
10. Preview: these skills prepare you for multiplying fractions next year!

items: Spinner labeled: Name It, Compare, Add, Subtract
