slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a mixed practice worksheet with 20 problems covering all four fraction skills in random order. Create a spinner with four sections: Name It (identify a fraction from a picture), Compare (use > < =), Add (same denominator), Subtract (same denominator). Have fraction circles accessible for all problems. Include a self-assessment checklist at the end.

slides.text: Subtracting fractions with the same denominator is just like adding, but in reverse. Instead of combining pieces, you TAKE AWAY pieces. 5/8 minus 2/8: you have 5 eighth-pieces and take away 2 of them. 5 minus 2 equals 3, so you have 3/8 left. The denominator stays the same because the SIZE of the pieces has not changed.

A special case: subtracting from a WHOLE number. What is 1 minus 3/4? First, convert 1 to a fraction with the same denominator: 1 = 4/4. Now: 4/4 minus 3/4 = 1/4. See it with fraction circles: start with a whole circle, take away the 3/4 piece, and 1/4 remains. This works for any whole number: 2 - 5/6 = 12/6 - 5/6 = 7/6 = 1 and 1/6.

Now let us put ALL our fraction skills together! This week we reviewed: NAMING fractions (numerator and denominator), COMPARING fractions (same denominator or same numerator), ADDING fractions (same denominator, add numerators), and now SUBTRACTING fractions (same denominator, subtract numerators). You have a complete fraction toolkit!

Fractions are not just math class problems — they are EVERYWHERE. When you follow a recipe and measure 3/4 cup of flour, that is fractions. When you eat 2 slices of an 8-slice pizza, you ate 2/8 or 1/4. When a song plays for 3 and 1/2 minutes, that is a fraction. When you have read 5/6 of your book, that is a fraction. The better you understand fractions, the better you understand the world.

slides.prompt:
Mixed Fraction Practice:
1. Subtraction problems (use fraction circles):
   5/6 - 2/6 = | 7/8 - 3/8 = | 4/5 - 1/5 = | 1 - 2/3 = | 1 - 5/8 = | 3/4 - 1/4 =
2. Mixed Practice Worksheet (20 problems): naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting fractions in random order
3. Spinner Game: Spin to determine the operation, then solve the fraction problem
4. Self-Assessment: Rate yourself 1-5 on each skill: Naming, Comparing, Adding, Subtracting. What is your strongest skill? What needs more practice?

slides.text: You now have a complete set of fraction skills! You can NAME fractions, COMPARE them, ADD them, and SUBTRACT them. These are the building blocks for everything you will learn about fractions in the future — multiplying, dividing, and working with different denominators. Be proud of how far you have come. Fractions are one of the most important topics in all of mathematics, and you have a solid foundation.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child subtract fractions with the same denominator? Can they subtract a fraction from a whole number? Can they perform all four fraction operations (name, compare, add, subtract) correctly? Can they apply fraction skills to word problems? Can they self-assess their strengths and areas for growth?

parent_notes: This mixed review is designed to consolidate all fraction learning from the week. The variety of problem types prevents rote memorization and requires children to think about what each problem is asking. The self-assessment component builds metacognition — awareness of one's own learning. If your child identifies a weak area, do extra practice in that specific skill rather than reviewing everything equally. The spinner game makes practice feel like play rather than drill. Real-world connections (cooking, pizza, measuring) help children see fractions as useful tools rather than abstract concepts. Consider doing some fraction cooking at home: recipes that call for halves, thirds, and fourths provide hands-on fraction practice that results in something delicious.

title: Healthy Habits — Hygiene, Handwashing, and Germ Prevention
description: Students learn about germs — bacteria and viruses — how they spread, and how simple hygiene habits prevent illness. They conduct a hands-on experiment demonstrating how germs transfer between surfaces and learn the proper handwashing technique recommended by health professionals.
instructions:
1. Connect to nutrition and sleep lessons: another pillar of health is CLEANLINESS.
2. What are germs? Tiny living things (bacteria) and particles (viruses) that can make us sick.
3. How germs spread: coughing, sneezing, touching surfaces, sharing food/drinks.
4. The glitter experiment: put glitter on hands, shake hands, touch surfaces — see how it spreads.
5. Handwashing: the #1 way to prevent illness. 20 seconds with soap and water.
6. Demonstrate proper technique: wet, soap, scrub (palms, backs, between fingers, under nails), rinse, dry.
7. When to wash: before eating, after bathroom, after sneezing/coughing, after playing outside.
8. Other hygiene habits: brushing teeth, bathing, clean clothes, covering coughs.
9. Students practice proper handwashing technique.
10. Create a 'Germ Prevention' poster for the classroom or home.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a handwashing station with soap, water, and paper towels. Have fine glitter ready for the germ-spreading demonstration. Prepare images or diagrams of bacteria and viruses at a child-friendly level. Have poster materials ready for the prevention poster activity. The glitter experiment is messy but memorable — lay down newspaper or do it outside.

slides.text: GERMS are tiny living things so small you cannot see them without a microscope. There are two main types: BACTERIA (tiny one-celled organisms) and VIRUSES (even tinier particles that invade your cells). Most bacteria are actually harmless or even helpful — the bacteria in your gut help you digest food! But some germs cause illness: colds, flu, stomach bugs, and infections. The question is: HOW do germs get from one person to another?

Germs spread in several ways. When you COUGH or SNEEZE, tiny droplets fly through the air carrying germs. When you TOUCH a surface (doorknob, table, phone) that a sick person touched, germs transfer to your hands. When you then TOUCH YOUR FACE (eyes, nose, mouth), the germs enter your body. This is called the CHAIN OF INFECTION. Let us see it in action with our glitter experiment!

[Glitter experiment.] The glitter on your hands represents germs. Now shake hands with a partner — look, the glitter transferred! Touch the table — glitter on the table. Touch your face — glitter on your face. This is EXACTLY how germs spread. Now, what BREAKS the chain? HANDWASHING! Wash your hands with soap for 20 seconds and watch the glitter disappear. Soap breaks apart germ cells and water washes them away.

Proper handwashing takes 20 SECONDS — sing 'Happy Birthday' twice. The technique: WET hands, add SOAP, then SCRUB everywhere: palms, backs of hands, between fingers, under fingernails, and wrists. RINSE under running water and DRY with a clean towel. Other hygiene habits matter too: brush teeth twice daily, bathe regularly, wear clean clothes, cover coughs with your elbow (not your hand!), and never share drinks or utensils with someone who is sick.

slides.prompt:
Three activities:
1. Glitter Germ Experiment: See how 'germs' spread from hands to surfaces to faces. Then wash thoroughly and observe how soap removes them.
2. Proper Handwashing Practice: Time yourself for 20 seconds. Did you scrub palms, backs, between fingers, and under nails?
3. Create a 'Germ Prevention' Poster: Include at least 5 hygiene tips with illustrations. Make it colorful and clear enough to hang in a bathroom or kitchen as a reminder.

slides.text: You cannot see germs, but they are everywhere — on every surface you touch, in every sneeze, on every doorknob. The GOOD NEWS is that simple habits protect you: wash your hands properly and often, cover your coughs, keep your body clean, and avoid touching your face with unwashed hands. These habits are the easiest and most effective way to stay healthy. You are now a germ-prevention expert!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what germs are and how they spread? Can they demonstrate proper 20-second handwashing technique? Can they list at least 5 times when handwashing is important? Can they describe at least 3 other hygiene habits that prevent illness?

parent_notes: The glitter experiment is one of the most memorable science demonstrations for children — they will think about it every time they touch a doorknob. The 20-second handwashing rule comes from the CDC and WHO, and singing 'Happy Birthday' twice is the child-friendly timer. Research shows that proper handwashing reduces respiratory illness by 21% and gastrointestinal illness by 31%. Make handwashing a non-negotiable habit at home: before meals, after bathroom, after coming inside. The germ prevention poster can be hung in the bathroom as a visual reminder. Avoid creating germ anxiety — the message should be empowering (you can PROTECT yourself) rather than frightening (germs are everywhere and dangerous). Most germs are harmless, and our immune system handles the rest when we support it with good habits.

title: Music — Song Writing Workshop Part 2
description: Students refine the songs they began in Part 1, adding a second verse, practicing melody, and preparing to perform their songs for the class. They learn about musical expression — how dynamics, tempo, and feeling transform lyrics into a real song.
instructions:
1. Review verse-chorus structure from Part 1.
2. Share: read your verse and chorus aloud — how does it sound?
3. Write a SECOND verse: same melody, different words, new detail about your topic.
4. Musical expression: DYNAMICS (loud vs. soft), TEMPO (fast vs. slow), FEELING.
5. Practice singing your complete song: verse 1, chorus, verse 2, chorus.
6. Add dynamics: which parts should be louder? Softer? Why?
7. Add expression: does your song sound happy? Sad? Excited? Match the feeling to the topic.
8. Small group sharing: sing for 2-3 classmates.
9. Peer feedback: what did you enjoy? What feeling did the song give you?
10. Final rehearsal before class performance.

items: Audio player for familiar melody reference
Simple percussion instruments if available (tambourine, shaker, drum)
slides.setup_instructions: Have students retrieve their lyrics from Part 1. Set up a small performance area. If percussion instruments are available, set them aside for optional accompaniment. Play the familiar melody they are using as a reference. Create a supportive atmosphere where sharing creative work feels safe and exciting rather than scary.

slides.text: Last time you wrote a verse and we created a chorus together. Today you will add a SECOND verse and turn your song into a complete performance. A second verse uses the SAME melody as the first verse but tells a DIFFERENT part of the story. Think of what else you want to say about your topic — a new detail, a new feeling, a new image.

Now let us add EXPRESSION. Dynamics means how LOUD or SOFT you sing. A gentle part of the song might be soft; an exciting part might be loud. Tempo means how FAST or SLOW. A happy part might be faster; a thoughtful part might be slower. And FEELING — does your song sound the way it SHOULD for its topic? A song about friendship should sound warm. A song about adventure should sound exciting.

Your complete song structure is: Verse 1, Chorus, Verse 2, Chorus. Some songwriters add a third verse or change the chorus slightly at the end. The important thing is that it FLOWS — one part leads naturally to the next. Practice singing it all the way through. If a line does not fit the melody, change a word or two until it does. Songwriters revise constantly — that is part of the creative process.

When you PERFORM your song, remember everything you learned about presentations: stand confidently, look at your audience, project your voice, and COMMIT to the performance. It is okay if your voice is not perfect — what matters is that you EXPRESS something real through your song. The audience wants to FEEL what you feel. Sing with your whole heart!

slides.prompt:
Complete and rehearse your song:
1. Write your second verse (4 lines, same melody as verse 1, new content)
2. Practice your full song: Verse 1 → Chorus → Verse 2 → Chorus
3. Add dynamics: mark which parts are louder (f) and softer (p) on your lyric sheet
4. Practice with expression and feeling
5. Perform for your small group (2-3 classmates)
6. Get feedback: What feeling did the song give the audience?
Optional: Add simple percussion accompaniment (clapping, tapping, or instruments)

slides.text: You are songwriters AND performers! You took an idea, organized it into verses and a chorus, set it to melody, added expression, and performed it for an audience. That is exactly what professional musicians do. Whether or not you become musicians, the skills you practiced today — creativity, structure, expression, and courage — will serve you in everything you do.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a second verse that fits the melody? Do they understand verse-chorus structure? Can they vary dynamics and expression in their singing? Can they perform their complete song for an audience? Can they give feedback about the feeling a song creates?

parent_notes: Songwriting workshop Part 2 builds on creativity with performance confidence. If your child is shy about singing, that is completely normal — encourage them gently but do not force. Some children prefer to speak their lyrics rhythmically rather than sing, and that is perfectly acceptable. The revision process (changing words to fit the melody) teaches that creativity involves editing, not just initial inspiration. If your child enjoyed this activity, encourage continued songwriting at home. You do not need musical training to support this — listening appreciatively and asking questions ('What is your song about? How does it make you feel?') is enough. Consider recording their song as a keepsake. The optional percussion accompaniment adds another layer of musical engagement.

title: Healthy Habits — Emotional Wellness and Stress Management
description: Students explore emotional health as a component of overall wellness. They learn to identify and name their emotions, understand that all feelings are normal, and practice healthy coping strategies for stress, frustration, and anxiety. They create a personal 'calm down toolkit.'
instructions:
1. Connect to previous health lessons: body health AND mind health matter equally.
2. What are emotions? Natural responses to what happens around us and inside us.
3. Naming emotions: expand vocabulary beyond happy/sad/mad — use a feelings chart.
4. All feelings are normal — there are no 'bad' emotions, only helpful and unhelpful RESPONSES.
5. What is stress? The body's response to challenges. Some stress helps; too much hurts.
6. Signs of stress: stomachache, headache, trouble sleeping, irritability, trouble focusing.
7. Healthy coping strategies: deep breathing, exercise, talking to someone, journaling, nature.
8. Deep breathing practice: 4 counts in, hold 4, out 4 (box breathing).
9. Students create a personal 'Calm Down Toolkit' — 5 strategies they will try.
10. Role-play: practice using a coping strategy in a stressful scenario.

items: Feelings chart with diverse emotion words
Optional: stress ball or fidget tool for demonstration
slides.setup_instructions: Create or print a feelings chart with at least 20 emotion words organized by category (happy family: joyful, excited, grateful, proud; sad family: disappointed, lonely, homesick; angry family: frustrated, annoyed, furious; scared family: nervous, worried, anxious). Prepare a Calm Down Toolkit template with space for 5 strategies and illustrations. Create a calm, comfortable atmosphere for this sensitive topic.

slides.text: We have been learning about keeping our BODIES healthy with good food, sleep, and exercise. But health includes our MINDS and FEELINGS too. EMOTIONAL WELLNESS means understanding your feelings, knowing that ALL feelings are normal, and having healthy ways to handle difficult emotions. Just like you brush your teeth to keep them healthy, you need tools to keep your emotional health strong.

Let us expand our feelings vocabulary. Most people say they feel 'happy,' 'sad,' or 'mad' — but there are SO many more feelings! You might feel PROUD when you finish something difficult, FRUSTRATED when you cannot figure something out, ANXIOUS when something new is coming, GRATEFUL when someone is kind, or LONELY when you miss a friend. The more precisely you can NAME your feeling, the better you can understand and manage it.

Here is an important truth: there are NO bad feelings. Anger is not bad — it tells you something is unfair. Fear is not bad — it keeps you safe. Sadness is not bad — it shows you care. The feelings themselves are normal and natural. What matters is what you DO with them. Punching a wall when angry is an unhelpful response. Taking deep breaths and talking about why you are angry is a helpful response.

When you feel stressed or overwhelmed, your body goes into 'fight or flight' mode — your heart beats faster, your muscles tighten, your breathing gets shallow. You can REVERSE this with calming strategies. Let us practice BOX BREATHING: breathe IN for 4 counts, HOLD for 4 counts, breathe OUT for 4 counts, HOLD for 4 counts. Repeat 4 times. Feel how your body calms down? This works EVERY time because it tells your brain that you are safe.

slides.prompt:
Create your personal Calm Down Toolkit:
1. Practice box breathing together (4 rounds)
2. Choose 5 coping strategies that work for YOU from this list: deep breathing, going for a walk, drawing, listening to music, talking to someone you trust, squeezing a stress ball, writing in a journal, counting to 10, doing yoga poses, spending time in nature
3. Write each strategy on your toolkit card and draw an illustration
4. Role-play: Your partner describes a stressful situation, you choose a strategy from your toolkit and practice using it
5. In your journal, write about a time you felt stressed and what helped (or what you wish you had done)

slides.text: Your emotional health is just as important as your physical health. Remember: all feelings are normal and valid. What matters is having TOOLS to handle difficult feelings in healthy ways. Your Calm Down Toolkit is personal — the strategies that work best are different for everyone. Keep your toolkit somewhere you can find it, and PRACTICE using the strategies when you are calm so they come naturally when you need them most.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 10 different emotions beyond happy/sad/mad? Do they understand that all feelings are normal? Can they demonstrate box breathing? Can they identify at least 5 healthy coping strategies? Can they distinguish between helpful and unhelpful responses to difficult emotions?

parent_notes: Emotional literacy is one of the most valuable skills we can teach children. Research shows that children who can identify and name their emotions have better self-regulation, stronger relationships, and improved academic performance. The key message — no bad feelings, only helpful and unhelpful responses — gives children permission to feel fully while teaching them responsibility for their actions. Box breathing is a scientifically validated technique that activates the parasympathetic nervous system. Practice it together during calm moments so it becomes automatic during stressful ones. The Calm Down Toolkit should live in an accessible place — on the fridge, in a backpack, by the bed. Model emotional wellness yourself: let your child see you name your feelings and use coping strategies. 'I am feeling frustrated right now, so I am going to take some deep breaths' teaches more than any lesson.

title: Presentation Day — Delivering Your Talk
description: Students deliver their final presentations to the class, showcasing everything they have learned about public speaking: organized content, confident delivery, effective visual aids, and audience engagement. Each student presents for 2-3 minutes followed by audience questions and celebration.
instructions:
1. Set up the presentation area: podium or designated spot, visual aid display area.
2. Review expectations: respectful listening, encouraging applause, thoughtful questions.
3. Warm-up: group box breathing to calm nerves.
4. Each student presents in turn (2-3 minutes each).
5. After each presentation: audience applause, then 1-2 questions from classmates.
6. Teacher notes strengths for each presenter on a celebration certificate.
7. Continue until all students have presented.
8. Group reflection: What did you learn from watching others?
9. Distribute celebration certificates acknowledging each student's unique strength.
10. Class discussion: How has your confidence in speaking grown this week?

items: Completed presentation plans and index cards
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a presentation area at the front of the room with space for visual aids. Arrange audience seating so everyone has a clear view. Prepare celebration certificates with each student's name and a blank line for their specific strength (to be filled in during presentations). Create a warm, supportive atmosphere. Consider making it special: a 'stage' area, perhaps with a podium or music stand for notes. Have the timer visible but not anxiety-inducing.

slides.text: Today is PRESENTATION DAY! You have planned your content, practiced your delivery, created a visual aid, and rehearsed with feedback. You are READY. Remember: every person in this room is cheering for you to succeed. We are an AUDIENCE, not judges. When you stand up to speak, you are sharing something you know and care about — and that is always worth hearing.

Before we begin, let us do our box breathing together to calm any butterflies. Breathe in 2-3-4, hold 2-3-4, out 2-3-4, hold 2-3-4. [Repeat 3 times.] Now remember the key skills: start with your HOOK, cover your THREE main points, use your VISUAL AID at the right moment, make EYE CONTACT, project your VOICE, and end with a strong CLOSING.

Audience members: your job is important too! SIT quietly and give your full attention to the speaker. LOOK at them, not at your desk. LISTEN to learn something new. CLAP after every presentation to show appreciation. Then you may ask ONE thoughtful question. Good questions: 'How did you learn about that?' 'Can you tell us more about...?' 'What is your favorite part about...?'

When it is your turn: take a deep breath, walk to the front, place your visual aid where everyone can see it, look at the audience, and BEGIN. If you forget something, glance at your cards. If you make a mistake, just keep going — the audience will not even notice most mistakes. The most important thing is that you TRIED and you SHARED. That takes real courage, and I am proud of every single one of you.

slides.prompt:
Presentation time!
1. Each student presents for 2-3 minutes
2. After each presentation: applause, then 1-2 audience questions
3. While watching: note one thing you admire about each presenter's style
4. After all presentations, group reflection:
   - What was the most interesting thing you learned from someone else's presentation?
   - What presentation skill are you most proud of developing this week?
   - How does it feel to have completed your presentation?

slides.text: You DID it! Every one of you stood up, spoke clearly, and shared something meaningful with this class. THAT is courage. THAT is confidence. The skills you used today — organizing your ideas, speaking with purpose, using visuals, connecting with an audience — are skills you will use for the rest of your life. Remember this feeling: you CAN speak in front of people, and you can do it WELL. Be proud of yourselves!
slides.mastery_check: Did the child deliver a complete presentation with an opening hook, body, and closing? Did they use appropriate volume, pace, eye contact, and posture? Did they integrate their visual aid effectively? Were they a respectful and engaged audience member? Can they reflect on their growth in public speaking?

parent_notes: Presentation Day is a milestone moment. Many children (and adults) rank public speaking as their greatest fear, so completing a presentation is a genuine achievement. Celebrate it accordingly. If your child is anxious beforehand, normalize the feeling and remind them of their preparation. After the presentations, ask specific questions about what they and their classmates presented — showing interest in the content validates their effort. The celebration certificate acknowledges each child's unique strength rather than ranking performances, which aligns with the Montessori philosophy that each child has individual gifts. If possible, ask your child to present to family members as well — this extends the practice and lets the whole family celebrate their growing confidence.

title: Fractions Review — Real-World Fraction Applications
description: Students apply their fraction knowledge to solve real-world problems involving cooking, measurement, time, money, and fair sharing. This culminating lesson demonstrates that fractions are practical tools used every day, not just abstract math concepts.
instructions:
1. Review all fraction skills learned this week.
2. Station 1: Cooking fractions — read a recipe and measure ingredients using fractions.
3. Station 2: Time fractions — what fraction of an hour is 15 minutes? 30 minutes? 20 minutes?
4. Station 3: Money fractions — what fraction of a dollar is a quarter? A dime? 50 cents?
5. Station 4: Measurement fractions — measure objects to the nearest 1/4 inch and 1/2 inch.
6. Station 5: Fair sharing — divide items equally among different numbers of people.
7. Students rotate through stations in small groups.
8. Record findings in a 'Fractions in Real Life' journal page.
9. Create a 'Fraction Fact' poster showing one real-world application.
10. Reflect: Where will you notice fractions this week?

items: Small items for fair sharing (crackers, blocks)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up 5 stations around the room, each with materials and an instruction card. Station 1 (Cooking): measuring cups, a simple recipe card, dry ingredients like rice or beans. Station 2 (Time): a clock face with movable hands. Station 3 (Money): play money. Station 4 (Measurement): rulers and small objects to measure. Station 5 (Sharing): countable items and group-size cards. Students rotate in small groups, spending 5-6 minutes per station.

slides.text: All week we have practiced fraction skills: naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting. Today you get to see WHY those skills matter — because fractions are EVERYWHERE in real life! You will visit 5 stations, each showing a different way fractions are used every single day. At each station, solve the problems and record your findings in your notebook.

COOKING uses fractions constantly: 1/2 cup of sugar, 3/4 teaspoon of vanilla, 1/3 cup of milk. If you double a recipe, you need to ADD fractions. If you cut a recipe in half, you need to divide fractions. TIME is fractions: 15 minutes is 1/4 of an hour. 30 minutes is 1/2 of an hour. Every time you look at a clock, you are reading fractions!

MONEY is fractions too: a quarter is 1/4 of a dollar (that is why it is called a QUARTER!). A dime is 1/10 of a dollar. 50 cents is 1/2 of a dollar. MEASUREMENT uses fractions: rulers are divided into halves, fourths, eighths, and sixteenths of an inch. And FAIR SHARING is pure fractions: dividing 12 cookies among 4 people means each person gets 12/4 = 3 cookies.

At each station, read the instruction card, solve the problems using your fraction skills, and record your work in your notebook. Work with your group — discuss your answers and check each other's work. Remember: the fraction circles in your mind should be as clear as the fraction circles on the table. You are becoming fraction EXPERTS!

slides.prompt:
Rotate through all 5 stations (5-6 minutes each):
Station 1 — Cooking: Measure out 1/2 cup, 1/4 cup, and 3/4 cup. If a recipe needs 1/4 cup sugar and 1/4 cup flour, how much total dry ingredient?
Station 2 — Time: Show 1/4 hour, 1/2 hour, 3/4 hour on the clock. What fraction of an hour is 20 minutes?
Station 3 — Money: What fraction of a dollar is each coin? How many quarters make a whole dollar?
Station 4 — Measurement: Measure 5 objects to the nearest 1/4 inch. Find something that is exactly 3 and 1/2 inches.
Station 5 — Sharing: Divide 12 items among 3 people, then 4, then 6. What fraction does each person get?

slides.text: Fractions are not just a topic in math class — they are tools you use every day without even realizing it. Every time you cook, tell time, handle money, measure something, or share fairly, you are using fractions. The skills you built this week — naming, comparing, adding, and subtracting fractions — will grow with you through every year of math and every area of life. You are fraction experts!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child apply fraction skills to real-world contexts (cooking, time, money, measurement, sharing)? Can they measure using fractional units? Can they connect fraction concepts to everyday situations? Can they explain why fraction understanding is practically useful?

parent_notes: This station-based lesson makes fraction learning tangible and memorable. The hands-on activities connect abstract math to concrete daily experiences. The cooking station is especially powerful because measuring ingredients provides immediate physical feedback. At home, continue making these connections: have your child help measure ingredients, discuss what time 'quarter past' means, ask what fraction of a pizza remains after dinner. The money connection is particularly useful: explaining that a quarter is literally 'one quarter of a dollar' reinforces both math and financial literacy. The fair sharing station connects fractions to the social concept of fairness — a motivating context for children. This culminating activity should leave children feeling that fractions are useful friends, not intimidating strangers.

title: Year in Review — Our Journey Through History
description: Students reflect on the entire year's history curriculum, from early humans through ancient civilizations, world cultures, and American history to the founding of the United States. They revisit the classroom timeline, identify connections between eras, and celebrate how much they have learned about the human story.
instructions:
1. Walk along the classroom timeline from the beginning of the year to now.
2. Early humans: What do you remember? Tools, fire, cooperation.
3. Ancient civilizations: Mesopotamia, Egypt, Indus Valley, China — what connected them? (Rivers!)
4. World cultures: Africa, Asia, Americas — how are human experiences similar everywhere?
5. American history: Native Americans, exploration, colonies, Revolution, Constitution.
6. The big question: What PATTERNS do you see across all of history?
7. Students choose their favorite historical topic and explain why.
8. Create a 'History Highlights' page — draw and label 5 favorite moments from the year.
9. Discuss: How does understanding history help us understand TODAY?
10. Celebrate: We are all part of the ongoing human story!
materials_needed: Photos or artifacts from the year's studies

items: Classroom timeline spanning the year's studies
History journals from throughout the year
Photos or artifacts from previous history lessons
World map with locations studied marked
slides.setup_instructions: Display the classroom timeline prominently. Gather any artifacts, projects, or materials from throughout the year's history lessons. Have students bring their history journals. Mark all locations studied on a world map. Create a celebratory atmosphere — this is a culmination of a year's learning. Consider having students sit in a circle for the discussion portions.

slides.text: What an incredible journey we have taken this year! Let us walk along our timeline and remember. We started millions of years ago with EARLY HUMANS in East Africa — gatherers and tool-makers who survived through cooperation and intelligence. We watched humans spread across the globe, develop agriculture, and build the first CIVILIZATIONS along great rivers: the Tigris and Euphrates, the Nile, the Indus, the Yellow River.

We explored the great ANCIENT CIVILIZATIONS: Mesopotamia with its writing and laws, Egypt with its pyramids and pharaohs, and the incredible achievements of cultures around the world. We traveled through Africa, Asia, and the Americas, discovering that EVERYWHERE humans settled, they created art, music, stories, governments, and technologies. Different places, but the same human drive to understand and improve our world.

Then we turned to AMERICAN HISTORY: the Native Americans who lived here for thousands of years, the European explorers who crossed the ocean, the colonies that grew along the East Coast, and the REVOLUTION that created a new nation based on the idea that people can govern themselves. We ended with the Constitution — a framework of compromise that still guides America today.

Here is the most important thing about history: it is not just a list of facts and dates. It is the story of US — human beings solving problems, creating beauty, making mistakes, and trying to do better. Every civilization we studied faced the same basic challenges: How do we feed everyone? How do we live together fairly? How do we pass our knowledge to the next generation? And YOU are the next chapter of this story.

slides.prompt:
History Year in Review:
1. Walk the timeline: stop at 5 points and share one thing you remember about each era
2. Create a 'History Highlights' page: draw and label your 5 favorite historical topics from this year
3. Write a paragraph: Choose your #1 favorite history topic. Why did it interest you? What did you learn?
4. Discussion circle: Share patterns you noticed across different civilizations and time periods
5. Final reflection: How does understanding history help you understand the world today?

slides.text: You have traveled through millions of years of human history this year. You know about early tool-makers, ancient civilizations, world cultures, and the founding of our nation. But more importantly, you have learned to THINK like historians — to ask questions, look for evidence, consider different perspectives, and find connections across time and place. The human story continues, and YOU are part of it. What will YOUR chapter say?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify major eras and civilizations studied this year? Can they describe connections and patterns across different historical periods? Can they explain why studying history is valuable? Can they articulate a personal connection to a historical topic?

parent_notes: This culminating lesson celebrates a year of historical learning while developing metacognition — awareness of what one has learned and how one learns. The timeline walk is a powerful visual that shows children how much ground they have covered. The pattern-recognition discussion (all civilizations need food, governance, and education) develops higher-order thinking and connects to Montessori's cosmic education philosophy. Your child has developed not just knowledge but historical THINKING skills: questioning sources, considering perspectives, and understanding cause and effect. These skills transfer to every subject and to life. Continue building historical awareness by visiting museums, reading historical fiction, watching documentaries, and discussing current events in historical context.

title: Healthy Habits — Year-End Wellness Plan
description: Students synthesize everything they have learned about health — nutrition, sleep, exercise, screen time, hygiene, and emotional wellness — into a comprehensive personal wellness plan. They set specific goals for the summer, create an action plan, and commit to taking care of their whole selves.
instructions:
1. Review all health topics: nutrition, sleep, exercise, screen time, hygiene, emotional wellness.
2. What does it mean to be TRULY healthy? Body, mind, and feelings all working well.
3. Self-assessment: rate each health area from 1-5 (how well am I doing?).
4. Identify strongest area and area needing most improvement.
5. Set one specific goal for each of the 6 health areas.
6. Create an action plan: What exactly will I DO to meet each goal?
7. Identify potential obstacles and solutions for each goal.
8. Students write their wellness plan on a special template.
9. Pair up and share plans — accountability partners for summer.
10. Sign a 'wellness commitment' to themselves.

slides.heading: My Wellness Plan
slides.subheading: Taking Care of My Whole Self

items: Wellness plan template with sections for all 6 health areas
slides.setup_instructions: Create a comprehensive wellness plan template with sections for: Nutrition, Sleep, Exercise, Screen Time, Hygiene, and Emotional Wellness. Each section should have space for: Current Self-Rating (1-5), Specific Goal, Action Steps, and Potential Obstacle + Solution. Prepare a 'Wellness Commitment' card that students can sign and keep. Gather all materials from previous health lessons for reference.

slides.text: This week we learned about SIX pillars of health: NUTRITION (fueling your body with balanced meals), SLEEP (9-12 hours for growth and brain function), EXERCISE (60 minutes of active play daily), SCREEN TIME (balanced and limited), HYGIENE (handwashing and cleanliness to prevent illness), and EMOTIONAL WELLNESS (understanding feelings and coping with stress). Together, these six areas create WHOLE HEALTH — body, mind, and feelings all working their best.

Let us do a SELF-ASSESSMENT. Rate yourself honestly from 1 to 5 on each area. 1 means 'I really need to work on this' and 5 means 'I am doing great!' No one is a 5 in everything — even doctors and athletes have areas to improve. The goal is not perfection; it is AWARENESS. Once you know where you stand, you can make a plan to grow.

For each area, set ONE specific goal. Not 'eat better' but 'eat a fruit or vegetable with every meal.' Not 'sleep more' but 'be in bed by 8:30 on school nights.' Specific goals are ACHIEVABLE goals. Then write your ACTION STEPS — exactly what you will do. Finally, think about OBSTACLES: what might get in the way? And what will you do about it? Planning for obstacles BEFORE they happen makes you much more likely to succeed.

Your wellness plan is a promise to YOURSELF. You deserve to feel strong, energized, clear-headed, and happy. No one else can do this for you — YOU are the one who decides what to eat, when to sleep, how to spend your time, and how to handle your feelings. That is a lot of power, and this plan helps you use it wisely. Let us make this commitment together.

slides.prompt:
Create your Personal Wellness Plan:
1. Self-Assessment: Rate yourself 1-5 in each area (Nutrition, Sleep, Exercise, Screen Time, Hygiene, Emotional Wellness)
2. For each area, write:
   - One specific, achievable goal
   - Two action steps to reach the goal
   - One potential obstacle and your solution
3. Identify your strongest health area and your biggest growth area
4. Share your plan with a partner — be accountability buddies for summer
5. Sign your Wellness Commitment card
6. Decorate your plan — make it something you WANT to look at every day!

slides.text: You now know more about health and wellness than most adults! You understand nutrition, sleep, exercise, screen time, hygiene, and emotional wellness — and you have a PLAN to take care of yourself. Health is not something that just happens — it is something you BUILD through daily choices. Every healthy meal, every good night of sleep, every hour of play, and every deep breath is an investment in YOUR future. Take care of yourselves this summer, and come back strong!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain all six pillars of health? Can they honestly self-assess their current habits? Can they set specific, achievable health goals? Can they identify obstacles and plan solutions? Do they understand that wellness is a personal responsibility and ongoing process?

parent_notes: This culminating health lesson empowers children to take ownership of their wellness — a core Montessori value. The self-assessment builds honest self-reflection. The specific goal-setting teaches executive function skills (planning, anticipating obstacles, creating action steps). The accountability partner concept adds social support. Over the summer, you can reference this plan periodically: 'What was your sleep goal? How are you doing with it?' Without pressure, these gentle check-ins maintain awareness. The signed commitment card is meaningful for children — they take promises seriously when they put their name on them. Post the wellness plan somewhere visible at home. Remember that your modeling matters most: children who see adults making healthy choices are far more likely to make healthy choices themselves.

title: End-of-Year Art Showcase — Celebrating Creative Growth
description: Students curate a personal art portfolio from the year's work, selecting their best and most meaningful pieces. They set up a gallery walk, present their portfolio to classmates, and reflect on their creative growth over the year — recognizing how their skills, confidence, and artistic voice have developed.
instructions:
1. Gather art projects from throughout the year.
2. Select 5-7 pieces that represent your best work or most meaningful work.
3. For each piece, write a small artist card: title, medium, and one sentence about why you chose it.
4. Arrange your portfolio on your designated display space.
5. Gallery walk: students walk around viewing each other's portfolios.
6. Gallery etiquette: look closely, read the artist cards, ask questions, give compliments.
7. Each student presents their favorite piece to the class (1 minute).
8. Group discussion: How has your art changed since the beginning of the year?
9. Reflect: What art skill are you most proud of learning?
10. Celebrate creativity and close the art year with gratitude and applause.
materials_needed: Art projects from throughout the year

items: Collected art projects from the full year
Index cards for artist statement cards
Optional: tablecloth or decorative paper for display tables
slides.setup_instructions: Ask students to bring in or gather all art projects from the year. If projects are stored at school, lay them all out for selection. Set up display areas around the room — one per student. Each area needs enough space for 5-7 pieces and artist cards. Create a gallery atmosphere: perhaps play quiet music, set up a 'gallery entrance,' and have a class exhibit title. The goal is to make children feel like real artists having a real show.

slides.text: Welcome to our END-OF-YEAR ART SHOWCASE! Artists create many works during their career, but they choose only their best pieces for exhibitions. Today YOU are the curator — you will select 5-7 pieces from your year of art that you are most proud of or that mean the most to you. This is YOUR show, and every piece tells a story about who you are as an artist.

For each piece in your portfolio, write an ARTIST CARD — this is what real galleries have next to every artwork. Your card should include: the TITLE of the piece, the MEDIUM (what materials you used: watercolor, colored pencil, collage, etc.), and ONE SENTENCE about why you chose this piece. Maybe it was your first time trying a new technique, or it reminds you of a favorite lesson, or you are simply proud of how it turned out.

During the GALLERY WALK, be a respectful and curious viewer. Look CLOSELY at each person's work — notice details, colors, techniques. READ the artist cards. If something catches your eye, ask the artist about it. Give SPECIFIC compliments: 'I love the way you used blue in the background' is better than 'nice picture.' Every artist has worked hard and deserves thoughtful attention.

After the gallery walk, each of you will present your FAVORITE piece to the whole class — just one minute to tell us what it is, how you made it, and why it is special to you. Then we will reflect together on how we have grown as artists this year. Look at your earliest work and your most recent — see the difference? That growth happened because you PRACTICED, EXPERIMENTED, and were BRAVE enough to try new things.

slides.prompt:
Create your art portfolio showcase:
1. Select 5-7 pieces from this year's artwork
2. Write an artist card for each piece (title, medium, one sentence about why you chose it)
3. Arrange your display in an attractive way
4. Gallery Walk: visit every classmate's display, look closely, read cards, give at least 3 specific compliments
5. Present your favorite piece to the class (1 minute)
6. Reflection: In your notebook, write about your growth as an artist this year — what can you do now that you could not do in September?

slides.text: Look at what you have created this year! Drawings, paintings, collages, sculptures, mixed media — each piece represents a moment of creativity, learning, and courage. Art is not about being 'talented' — it is about SEEING the world with curious eyes, EXPRESSING what you feel and think, and being BRAVE enough to put it on paper. You are all artists, and I cannot wait to see what you create next year and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select and curate a portfolio from their body of work? Can they write meaningful artist statements? Can they present their work confidently? Can they give specific, constructive feedback to peers? Can they reflect on their artistic growth over the year?

parent_notes: The art showcase is a powerful culminating experience that builds confidence, metacognition, and pride. Curating a portfolio teaches critical thinking — selecting your 'best' work requires evaluating your own output. The artist cards develop writing skills in an authentic context. The gallery walk teaches art appreciation and respectful peer interaction. If possible, invite parents or family to view the gallery — public appreciation of children's art is enormously motivating. Save the portfolio and artist cards; they become a meaningful record of your child's growth. When children compare their September work to their May work, the improvement is often dramatic and deeply encouraging. This lesson reinforces that creativity is a skill that grows with practice, not an innate gift that some have and others do not.
